HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Roommate Overcharges Risk Lease

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
THOUSANDS of New York City rent-stabilized tenants who have roommates could be in danger of losing their apartments, landlord-tenant lawyers say, because of a recent ruling by a Manhattan appeals court.
 On Dec. 31, 2001, a three-judge panel of the Appellate Term, First Department, upheld an earlier ruling by a Manhattan Housing Court judge who refused to dismiss an eviction action brought by a landlord against a tenant who was alleged to be charging her roommate more than the roommate's proportionate share of the rent. The appellate court agreed that such an overcharge would violate a provision of the Rent Stabilization Code that prohibits tenants from profiteering from their financial arrangements with roommates, and sent the case back to the Housing Court for trial. 
 Lawyers who represent landlords say the decision appropriately prevents rent-stabilized tenants from profiting from their below-market-rate rents -- and, at the same time, protects roommates from paying more than their fair share of the rent. Tenants' lawyers say that the ruling interferes with the private financial relationships of tenants and roommates and could result in landlords aggressively pursuing eviction cases against tenants with roommates. 
In fact, the tenants' lawyers say, profiteering is considered a "noncurable" violation of the rent code. Even tenants who are now overcharging their roommates but who are willing to adjust the rent to comply with the law may find that it is too late to do so.
"I believe that there's going to be an emptying of apartments in New York City at a rate we've never seen before," said Darnay Hoffman, the Manhattan lawyer who represented the tenant in the case just decided. "What this means is that even in cases where a roommate is happy paying more than his proportionate share of the rent, the landlord becomes the gatekeeper. It means that the landlord is now in a position to interject himself into the private arrangements of people who are living together. And, worst of all, it's a noncurable violation of the code. That means you don't get a second chance to do it right."
Mr. Hoffman explained that the underpinning of the case was an amendment to the Rent Stabilization Code adopted on Dec. 20, 2000, by the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the state agency that administers the rent laws.
Prior to that date, he said, there was nothing in the code that prevented tenants in rent-stabilized apartments from charging their legal roommates whatever rent the roommate was willing to pay. The amendment adopted by the agency, however, prohibits tenants in New York City from charging roommates more than the roommate's proportionate share of the rent. (The prohibition does not extend to rent-stabilized tenants elsewhere in the state.)
Under the amendment, Mr. Hoffman said, a roommate's proportionate share of the rent is determined by dividing the legal regulated rent by the number of occupants in the apartment and the number of tenants named on the lease.
For purposes of determining proportionate share, a married couple whose names appear on the lease would be counted as one tenant, and immediate family members of the tenant, along with dependent children of any roommate, would not be counted. 
So, for example, the proportionate share of the rent for a roommate who lived with a married couple with a child would be 50 percent. The same proportion would apply to a roommate who lived with a lone tenant or with a lone tenant and the roommate's dependent child.
According to the Appellate Court's written decision -- RAM 1 L.L.C. v. Mazzola -- Mr. Hoffman's client, Joan E. Mazzola, whose rent-stabilized rent was $1,847.77 a month, was alleged to be charging her roommate, Brian Moro, $2,200 a month. When the landlord learned of the overcharge, it started an eviction action against Ms. Mazzola based upon her alleged violation of section 2525.7(b) of the Rent Stabilization Code, the amendment that prohibits charging a roommate more than a proportionate share of the rent.
Mr. Hoffman then filed a motion to dismiss the case, allowing that for purposes of the motion only, the allegations were true. Judge Larry S. Schachner of the Housing Court denied the motion -- a decision that has now been upheld by the Appellate Term -- ruling that the eviction action could proceed and that, if the allegations are proved to be true, Ms. Mazzola and her roommate can be evicted from the apartment.
While that alone would be troubling enough for Ms. Mazzola and other tenants who are charging their roommates more than their proportionate share of the rent, what is particularly painful is that violation of the antiprofiteering section of the code is a noncurable violation.
William Neville, a Manhattan lawyer who represented RAM 1 L.L.C., the landlord, explained that most eviction actions brought by landlords against tenants for violations of the terms of the lease were curable violations. If the tenant ceases the action that is causing the violation, he said, the tenant cannot be evicted.
In fact, Mr. Neville said, even in cases where a landlord prevails in an eviction case for violation of the lease, the court typically gives the tenant 10 days to avoid being evicted by curing the violation.
The case brought by Mr. Neville's client, however, did not allege that Ms. Mazzola violated the lease, but instead that she violated a section of the Rent Stabilization Code that does not permit a cure -- either before or after the case is decided.
"That means that if the trial court accepts our version of the facts" -- that Ms. Mazzola was charging her roommate more than his proportionate share of the rent -- "then we're entitled to possession and she has no right to cure," Mr. Neville said.
He added that the result is ultimately appropriate since a tenant who is charging a roommate an excessive amount of rent is taking advantage of the protections the rent laws were intended to provide.
"The Rent Stabilization Law was designed to prevent people from paying oppressive rents," Mr. Neville said. "And it does that by limiting the rent a landlord can charge. Given that fact, why should a tenant be allowed to take advantage of the rent laws and gain profits that the owner of the property cannot get?"
He added that while the Rent Stabilization Code does not require a tenant to divulge how much a roommate is being charged, there are various ways a landlord can obtain such information. In some cases, Mr. Neville said, the tenant advertises the apartment and the rent being sought. In others a disgruntled former roommate might provide the information.
Once a landlord has reasonable grounds to believe that a tenant is violating the code, the landlord can start an eviction action. When that happens, the landlord can call the roommate as a witness at the trial and ask him how much rent he is paying to the tenant. 
Lucas Ferrara, a Manhattan lawyer who represents both landlords and tenants, said there were legitimate arguments on both sides.
"The amendment to the law was in response to situations where tenants were gaining financial benefits from their regulated status," Mr. Ferrara said.
At the same time, he said, the inflexible manner in which the law defined a roommate's proportionate share of the rent could produce some seemingly unfair results.
For example, Mr. Ferrara said, the law does not account for situations in which the roommate agrees to pay more than his or her proportionate share of the rent because the roommate has the use of more space in the apartment than the tenant.
Mr. Hoffman, who said it was unlikely that he would get the permission necessary to appeal the case to a higher court, said the law could actually end up hurting the roommates it was intended to protect.
"Think about it for a minute," he said. "If the tenant gets evicted, the roommate goes, too."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
For Single-Screen Theaters, the Next Act

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE

 BODY:
WITH multiscreen movie theaters now an integral part of today's entertainment, most of Long Island's original single-screen theaters, once owned by the giants in the movie industry, have lost their audience. Unprofitable in their original function, most old theaters have been bought by developers or local entrepreneurs who have proposed various uses for what was once a strong economic anchor for downtown businesses.
 In Nassau, plans are under way to convert a former theater in Great Neck Estates into a condominium with a two-story parking garage. A two-story office building is planned for a single-screen theater in Woodbury that has been vacant since last spring. 
 Farther east, in Suffolk, the 72-year-old single-screen theater on Smithtown's Main Street was recently sold for $425,000 to a group of local residents who plan to restore it for use as a center for the performing arts. 
In some cases, the creative direction taken by the current owners of the old theaters has evolved along with the bankruptcies of some major theater companies. 
In restructuring their companies, "some have sold off the smaller, older and less profitable theaters," said Mitch Neuhauser, associate executive director for the National Association of Theater Owners of New York State.
Mark Walsh, a principal in Select Investment Realty Advisers, a commercial investment brokerage firm in Hauppauge, said: "Many theater companies went into bankruptcy because they were building new theaters too fast. They also owned a lot of old theaters that were economically obsolete, and which didn't fit the modern design of what people wanted. It was too expensive to retrofit, and often there wasn't enough space. 
"People going to the theater today want their creature comforts, reclining seats with cup holders, good heating and the good view offered by stadium-type seating." As a consultant for United Artists, Mr. Walsh has sold off $25 million of real estate for the company in the New York City region, including the Smithtown Theater.
United Artists, which emerged from six months of bankruptcy last February, "has restructured and is now in the market for new opportunities," said Scott Hall, director of real estate for United Artists Theater Circuit Inc., which is based in Denver.
In 1996, with 76 screens, the company owned 16 of Long Island's 61 theaters. Four of those were single-screen theaters -- in Smithtown, Northport, Lindenhurst and Westhampton Beach. 
United Artists now owns 74 screens in 9 of Long Island's 62 theaters, ranging from 13 screens at the Patchogue Multiplex Theater to 4 at the Southampton Theater. 
All four single-screen theaters have been sold, Mr. Hall said. "Smithtown was the last one and we're glad to see it go to someone who will give it the attention it deserves," he said.
United Artists will now focus on renovating and enlarging its multiscreen theaters, he said. This includes adding stadium seating and increasing the size of its Lynbrook theater to 50,000 square feet from 23,000 square feet and adding six screens to the six already there. 
Thomas Fitzsimmons, an architect in Great Neck, said he was working on the conversion of a brick building with decorative stonework that began as a legitimate vaudeville theater in 1922 called the Playhouse Theater in Great Neck Estates. 
The theater occupies 7,000 square feet in the rear of an 11,000-square-foot four-story building on Middle Neck Road, the village's main street. The front of the building includes 4,000 square feet of retail stores on the grade level and six apartments on the three stories above that, which were part of the original structure.
Around 1930, the theater was bought by United Artists to show movies. It was sold in 1980 to a group that tried to use it for local acting groups. That venture failed and in 1982 the theater use was eliminated and the building was renovated, Mr. Fitzsimmons said. The lower level, which contained the seats, was remodeled into an indoor parking lot. 
THREE years ago, the new owner, the First Playhouse of Great Neck Corporation, a Manhattan development group, started the process of turning the former theater space into apartments.
The proposed $3.5 million project, which is now in the permit stage, would include converting the 48-foot-high interior volume of the former theater into two levels that would include 12 luxury one- and two-bedroom apartments and adding two levels of parking to accommodate 30 cars. The apartments, including three duplexes, would range from 850 to 1,600 square feet.
The six original apartments are to be renovated and the retail area reduced to 3,000 square feet to allow for the parking garage. Upon completion of the project, all units are to be sold as condominiums, Mr. Fitzsimmons said. 
In Suffolk, the 544-seat Smithtown theater, which includes an 86-seat balcony, is known for its Art Deco interior. On Jan. 11, the theater was bought by the Smithtown Theater Holding Company.
The 8,190-square-foot building had been showing second-run films for $2 until it closed two years ago. Plans for the theater include showing cultural films and presenting performances by professional artists and a local children's musical theater group. 
Ken Washington, former director of the Smithtown Township Arts Council, who spearheaded a drive to keep the theater "as an establishment for the arts," said: "It is not in bad condition. Imminent plans include some minor renovations, enlarging the stage, removing some seats and updating the lighting and heating."
The new owners of the theater, Mr. Washington said, "are basically local residents who have an altruistic purpose, rather than one of profit; they purchased it for the good of the community." Mr. Washington is one of the principals. 
The former 1,100-seat Syosset Theater is one of the original buildings in the 42-building corporate park owned by the Tilles Companies in Woodbury. The corporate park, Nassau Crossways International Plaza, was created 40 years ago on a 135-acre carefully landscaped site. The theater, which was built in 1960, had been leased by United Artists until last spring and has remained vacant since. Tilles is planning to divide the building into two 12,000-square-foot floors of office space, each housing one tenant, according to Philip Wachtler, Tilles's director of leasing and development. 
The demise of the traditional one-screen theater is all part of a change in lifestyle, said James Thomas Martino, a Port Washington architect who has designed movie theaters throughout the country and in South America for the last 18 years. 
"It is very exciting today -- the theater has grown and has become more of a total night-out experience," he said. "You are not just being funneled through a building to a dark room."
The typical theater being built today has 15 to 24 screens and has total space of 80,000 to 100,000 square feet, he said. 
"It is more of a meeting place with cafes, game rooms and some even have combined restaurants," said Mr. Martino, who designed three theaters on Long Island for the Canada-based Cineplex Odeon, which has since been bought by Sony Entertainment of New York City.
HIS projects include a new six-screen theater for downtown Glen Cove and the conversion of a one-screen theater at the Smith Haven Mall to four screens. Four years ago, Mr. Martino designed a new eight-screen, 48,217-square-foot theater in downtown Huntington on the site of the town's old one-screen theater, which had been demolished.
Because of property constraints, even those theaters are small compared with others being built around the country, Mr. Martino said. He cited a 17-screen, 78,482-square-foot theater -- called The Palace -- with 3,611 seats he designed for Crown Theaters in Hartford in 2000. The 4,500-square-foot lobby was designed with a raised dome with fiber-optic stars projected above "to create a mystical ambience," he said.
While there are large, modern 16- and 17-screen theaters built by the Boston-based National Amusements in Hicksville and Commack, they are in the minority, Mr. Martino said.
"The difficulty on Long Island is finding the property to build a grand theater," he said. "Besides the building site, there is the land required for parking, which is one car space for every four seats. There is no land left in Nassau, and the demand out east is not as great."

HEADLINE: CITIES; 
In Hoboken, the Mayor Wants Partying Toned Down a Bit

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL

DATELINE: HOBOKEN 

 BODY:
ABOUT 11:30 on a recent Friday night, 27-year-old Roberto Toscano and a half-dozen friends stood shivering and smoking cigarettes in front of Oscar's Groceries.
 The group of 20-something guys had just tried to get into the popular place known simply as the bar at 10th and Willow, where they were hoping -- to use more delicate terms than their own -- to meet some attractive young women. 
 But the bar was at the 249-person capacity set by the local fire code, and instead of having them get in line -- as he used to -- the managing partner, Mario Steriti, jotted down their cellphone numbers and told them to move on and wait for his call.
A new no-line policy -- the result of a meeting early last month between city officials and restaurant and bar owners -- has become the latest flash point in an intermittent debate over the quality of life that has emerged as Hoboken has developed a reputation as a party town. Residents complain of revelers making noise, urinating in public and occasionally destroying property late at night and into the early morning. 
The rule is intended to reduce congregations of young people by having them move on to other bars, and many do. But some, like Mr. Fowler and company, simply loiter on surrounding blocks, waiting for a call or passing the entrance every few minutes to see if spots have opened up.
"Residents can't be happy about this, because people are outside making noise," said Mr. Toscano, an advertising consultant from Rockland County, N.Y.
Anne-Marie Pelletier begs to differ. She, her husband and their three school-age children live in a brownstone across 10th Street from where the line used to form outside the bar. Ms. Pelletier was the first to suggest the no-lines idea to Mayor David Roberts. 
The bar line was loud, she said, but not because Mr. Steriti did not do everything he could to keep it quiet.
"Drunks are noisy," said Ms. Pelletier. "Groups of drunks are noisier. There's nothing you're going to do to get away from that. It's a simple fact of life. When they come to your neighborhood week after week and they pollute your home with noise, you get angry. You get resentful."
As a result, in the fall she and other residents formed a group called Stop Toxic Unnecessary Noise, or STUN.
Night life, to a large extent, is the reason this river city has flourished over the past two decades. Several bar owners criticized the new policy, saying they were pressured into agreeing to it under veiled threats of harsher measures like pushing up closing time from 3 a.m. to 1 a.m.
"It's hard for me to tell people, 'Don't come in here,' " said Mr. Steriti. "We work as hard as we do to make the people want to come here. They have to want to be here to come here. To send them away is scary. Six months from now they are not going to come back."
Over the past 20 years, Hoboken has attracted increasing numbers of young professionals and families escaping Manhattan rents. A debate about overdevelopment became the centerpiece of the mayoral election last May, in which Mr. Roberts defeated the two-term incumbent, Anthony Russo. 
It is a place where politics, friendships and businesses intertwine, sometimes uncomfortably. Mayor Roberts, whose family owns property and runs restaurants in town, said that his brother, Charles, has chided him for not supporting the industry that supported his family for decades. One of the bar owners outraged over the new lines policy, Dave Carney of the Madison Bar and Grill on Washington Street, Hoboken's main drag, pays $4,500 a month in rent to the mayor's brother, his landlord.
The new mayor said that he was approaching the bar issue with an open mind and that he was willing to hear suggestions. "We're not racing in with our police department and we're not changing laws that are very aggressively hurting businesses," he said. "But we're firm, we're holding our position." He said more police officers had been moved to the night shift to patrol the streets around the bars.
Some owners of more upscale restaurants and bars are pleased with the no-lines policy, which they hope will make Hoboken more attractive to a less rowdy crowd, which already makes up a good part of the social scene. 
"The mayor is being proactive and saying, 'What can you do about this before it becomes a big problem again?' " said Eugene Flinn, who took over the highly regarded Amanda's restaurant when the mayor's immediate family sold it in 1996. He said other measures were also discussed at the meeting, including hiring crews to clean the streets between 3 and 5 a.m. 
Mr. Flinn said he had also made sacrifices in the interest of community relations. He would love to open the yard behind his restaurant to outdoor dining in the warm months, he said, but will not because the neighbors are against it.
Owners of the bars that are affected said they were against the agreement.
"I think it's crazy you would ask businesses to turn away business," said Mr. Carney. "Slower bars in town will benefit from the more successful ones. Why should mediocre bars benefit from our success?"
But Mayor Roberts and owners of the more upscale establishments are skeptical about that argument. "Your establishment is already filled to capacity, so the line is just a guarantee that for every person that leaves there's one that comes in," he said. "I understand their business and it's of no economic consequence."
But others counter that in a highly competitive bar town in a faltering economy, keeping a place filled on weekend nights is crucial to their success. Javier Barreiro, a manager at Rodeo, another popular bar on Washington Street, suggested reinstating lines but limiting their length.
Luisa Esposito, 31, and Eric Nastri, 33 are exactly the kind of people that the mayor hopes to please. The couple, who are expecting a child, live down the street from the bar at 10th and Willow, but rarely frequent it. The policy might not directly help them, they say, but they support it.
"I think if you live directly above the bar, or across the street, I can understand how it could get a little quieter," Mr. Nastri said. 
But, Ms. Esposito added: "The bigger problem is after they leave the bars. They're wasted and they destroy things."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 3, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about a mayoral ban in Hoboken on waiting lines outside the city's bars misstated the role of Dave Carney, who opposes the policy. He is the general manager of the Madison Bar and Grill; the owner is his wife, Kristian L. Carney.

HEADLINE: In Brooklyn, Projects, Plans and Hopes 

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
AS construction work begins on 9 MetroTech South, a 670,000-square-foot building that will house 1,300 employees of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, planning is under way to lay the zoning and other groundwork for other development in downtown Brooklyn. 
 While the new building will complete development of the 16-acre MetroTech complex, its developer and others active in the borough think Brooklyn could become increasingly attractive to companies that are expanding or that want to spread out their work forces for increased security in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, while still remaining in the city. 
 To help make this happen, efforts are under way to revise the zoning for certain parts of the downtown area to permit the construction of buildings -- both office towers and housing -- larger than zoning now permits. The designated sites include four blocks along Livingston Street between Smith Street and Flatbush Avenue, several blocks on both sides of Willoughby Street near Flatbush Avenue and several blocks on the east side of Flatbush Avenue closer to the Brooklyn Bridge. 
Others are working to add amenities by upgrading or expanding two existing malls. Work is to begin next month above the Long Island Rail Road's Brooklyn terminus on the four-story, 400,000-square-foot Atlantic Terminal Mall, almost half of which is to be occupied by a Target department store. The project includes foundation work for an eventual office tower, and city and Metropolitan Transportation Authority crews have been preparing the site for construction. 
Some customers for the malls are expected to come from the area's student population, which will take on a more 24-hour character with the opening of a new dormitory this fall, with another one, at a different school, also being planned. 
Further in the future -- with the other demands on city and state coffers raising questions about timing -- are ambitious plans for developing a park along the waterfront below Brooklyn Heights and, in the area around the Brooklyn Academy of Music, expanding cultural facilities while adding housing and office space.
Since many of these projects are dependent on city money, they are likely to be delayed by the current budget pressures. But backers say the preliminary work is necessary to prepare the area so that developers will be able to move quickly when demand is felt from companies that are expanding or are relocating some of their offices.
"Downtown Brooklyn has got to be ready to go in the next up-cycle," said James Whelan, director of the Downtown Brooklyn Council. The council is asking city planners to increase zoning in the designated locations to permit the development of 12 million square feet of space: 9 million commercial and 3 million residential.
He said residential construction was an important part of the plan to create what he terms "a true downtown." He added, "We need to have people here after 5:30 in the afternoon." One criticism of MetroTech has been that while thousands of people work there during the day, most leave for homes elsewhere in the city or in the suburbs after office hours, leaving the streets empty and lifeless.
Similarly, educational institutions in downtown Brooklyn are trying to turn at least a small number of the estimated 30,000 students who flood into the area each day into residents. As part of a $100 million renovation and expansion of its Brooklyn campus, Polytechnic University has built its first dormitory, a 400-bed facility that is scheduled to open in the fall. Brooklyn Law School has announced plans to build its first dormitory as well, with 350 beds, at the northwest corner of Boerum Place and State Street.
Having a larger 24-hour population should attract retailers and make the neighborhood more attractive to companies looking for office space, Mr. Whelan said. "We serve Midtown and lower Manhattan, and we compete with the New Jersey waterfront," he said. Also among potential competitors is Long Island City, Queens, where a 37-block area was rezoned for greater density last year, although no projects are yet under way.
WHILE planners and developers agree that new commercial projects will most likely wait for the next economic upturn, the development of 9 MetroTech South is an indication of how fast things can happen when a site is ready to go and there is a client in need.
Before Sept. 11, the Forest City Ratner Companies, the developer of MetroTech, did not have an anchor tenant for the site, at the northwest corner of Myrtle Avenue and Flatbush Avenue Extension, and had no plans to build.
Then, "the deal was done in two months," said Bruce C. Ratner, the company's president, of the decision by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to sign a lease for 322,220 square feet, or about one-half the 19-story building. Because the company's employees are currently scattered in different locations, construction is proceeding urgently. "We are working double shifts and should have the building ready in 18 months, rather than the 24 to 30 months it would usually take," he said.
Mr. Ratner said events of Sept. 11 appeared to have changed corporate attitudes toward Brooklyn. In the past, financial services companies placed back-office operations in the borough because the rents were lower, while keeping their headquarters in Manhattan. Now, he said, there is interest in moving whole entities to Brooklyn, which is, among other things, on a different power grid than Manhattan.
"Prior to this, downtown Brooklyn was strictly a low-cost alternative," he said. "Now companies that are interested in spreading out their space are interested in Brooklyn for reasons not based solely on costs."
Dr. George Bugliarello, the chancellor of Polytechnic and also the conceptual father of MetroTech, said Sept. 11 might lead corporate executives, city officials and developers to question the value of concentrating businesses in Manhattan. "In medieval times cities were a place of protection," he said. "Now cities are hostages, and we have to rethink the distribution of activity."
But he said it would be difficult to replicate MetroTech, because few developers are willing to take on a $1 billion project that takes 15 years to plan and build.
In addition to the developers of office and academic projects, retail developers are paying increasing attention to downtown Brooklyn. Joseph J. Sitt, the principal owner of Thor Equities, a real estate investment company, has purchased the somewhat threadbare Albee Square Mall, between Flatbush Avenue and Fulton and Gold Streets, and plans to transform it into an upscale shopping center called the Gallery at Fulton Street.
Mr. Sitt, who developed the Ashley Stewart retail clothing chain, aimed at urban women, into a business with annual sales of more than $300 million, said there is money to be made in urban locations as well as suburban malls. He said the first task is to fix the leaky roof of the three-story mall, but then he plans to improve the appearance of the entire building. "I'm going to rip out the linoleum floors and replace them with granite," he said.
He said that in the late 1990's companies he calls "white-bread retailers" discovered the urban market, increasing competition for Ashley Stewart, and Mr. Sitt sold his interest in the company. He said he decided to buy real estate in urban areas to present a variety of retail concepts. The mall has Toys "R" Us as one anchor, and Mr. Sitt said he was hoping to attract a department store as another anchor.
He said the plan is to create the same shopping experience as in top quality suburban areas. "We are going to take the finest quality mall in white, suburban areas and bring it to downtown Brooklyn," he said.
The site includes a five-story parking garage that Thor Equities owns and is in one of the areas designated for increased zoning. Mr. Sitt said he is prepared to demolish the existing structure and build a 900,000-square-foot building if a tenant signs a lease without waiting for the zoning to change. He said he would build it in such a way that it could be expanded if the zoning is changed to allow 2.5 million square feet of development. Included in that figure would be another building over the retail space.
More immediate retail development plans are about to be executed by Forest City Ratner on a 3.6-acre site bounded by Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues, Hanson Place and Fort Greene Place. The mall, to be called Atlantic Terminal, is to sit atop the Long Island Rail Road terminal, which is connected to 10 subway lines. Forest City Ratner officials say 50 million subway, commuter rail and bus passengers pass by the location each year.
The 400,000-square-foot, four-story Atlantic Terminal will be adjacent to the Atlantic Center retail mall, which opened in 1996. Atlantic Terminal is the third and final phase of the project, which also includes 417 units of owner-occupied affordable housing and a public park.
The anchor store for Atlantic Terminal will be a 194,000-square-foot Target discount department store. Other retailers that have signed leases at the project include Payless Shoesource, Rockaway Bedding, Daffy's and Avenue, a women's clothing store. These stores will join Macy's, Pathmark, Old Navy and Circuit City, which are already in operation at Atlantic Center.
Work on Atlantic Terminal is scheduled to begin next month, with completion scheduled for March 2004.
Mr. Ratner said an office building could be built on top of the retail space at Atlantic Terminal and Center if demand warrants.
CLOSER to Fort Greene Park, the BAM Local Development Corporation is seeking to establish a residential and cultural district on land that is now used mostly for surface parking lots. The district would be anchored by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, hence the name.
"Our goal is to develop a mixed use, multicultural arts district by using underused city-owned property," said Jeanne Lutfy, president of the development group. (Harvey Lichtenstein, the former president of the music academy, is chairman.)
She said the plan is to develop low-cost housing along with cultural, meeting and rehearsal spaces so there will be people on the streets day and night. She said the city had earmarked $80 million in its capital budget, with additional financing expected from the state and programs intended to promote the development of affordable housing.
One of the group's first projects is the renovation of 80 Hanson Place, a 30,000-square-foot state-owned building that had stood vacant for 10 years. The development corporation will renovate the building as offices and meeting spaces for small nonprofit arts groups, with the work scheduled to start in March and to be completed by the end of the year. Part of the financing is coming from the city and the remainder from a $1 million grant from the state.
Already in the area is the Mark Morris Dance Center, which opened last fall in a long-vacant space after a $7 million renovation. The center includes a permanent home for the Mark Morris Dance Group along with space for dance classes for the public and dance rehearsal space for rent to outside groups.
Ms. Lutfy said the next project is the development of the so-called East Site with the ubiquitous Mr. Ratner, who controls the property. She said that it would be a mix of about 50,000 square feet of cultural space and 100,000 square feet of housing and that construction should begin early in 2003 and be complete by the end of the year. City funding is to pay for the cultural part, and existing housing programs are expected to be tapped to aid the residential component.
Plans for the other parcels of land are further in the future, she said, particularly the West Site, which is entirely in private hands.
While plans for the cultural district develop, another local development corporation is seeking to develop a public park along the East River waterfront. It is to run from the footing of the Manhattan Bridge past the developing Dumbo neighborhood past the Brooklyn Bridge and south onto piers little used by their owner, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The park would cover 67 acres of land stretching from Jay Street in the north to Atlantic Avenue in the south.
The park would include some commercial development, including a hotel and conference center. But officials of the Brooklyn Bridge Park Development Corporation say 80 percent of the park will be open space in an area of the city with little of it.
Like many waterfront areas of New York, the industrial docks near the Fulton ferry landing were made obsolete by the emergence of containerized shipping and the development of container ports in New Jersey. Joanne Witty, the president of the development corporation, said the park would emerge "as the industrial glacier recedes from the waterfront."
Ms. Witty said the park has an $85 million commitment from the state through the Port Authority, which is treating the pilings supporting the docks to prevent further damage from marine pests, and $65 million from the city. She said she thought the state commitment was solid, but admitted that the city funds have to be appropriated on a yearly basis. "The park can be seen as economic development that provides jobs and improves the attractiveness of the harbor," Ms. Witty said.
Ferry service is expected to resume this summer between the Fulton Landing and various points in Manhattan. The 90-passenger boats are to be operated by New York Water Taxi.
Retail and leasing activity have been increasing in the Dumbo area, said Jed D. Walentas, an executive of the Two Trees Management Company, which owns and manages most of the buildings in the area. He said Williams-Sonoma, a housewares and cookware company, is building two separate design studios on the eighth and ninth floors of the building at 55 Washington Street, and ABC Carpet has been holding warehouse sales in 40,000 square feet of space at 20 Jay Street while negotiating for a permanent location.
He said his company is also prebuilding small office spaces in the 2,000- to 4,000-square-foot range for design, architectural and consulting companies at the rate of "about a dozen a month."
Also in Dumbo, Jeffrey M. Brown Associates is planning a mixed-use development on what is now a surface parking lot on Jay Street between Front and York Streets. The proposed development, called Light Bridges at 100 Jay Street, would include retail stores and office space in the base of the building and two residential towers connected by a light bridge.
Since the site slopes 17 feet downward toward the East River, the building incorporates an unusual design. "We are going to have one and one half levels of retail with about 24,000 to 30,000 square feet of space and one and a half levels of parking for 250 to 260 cars," Mr. Brown said. Five levels of office space would be on top of the retail space and rise to the level of the deck of the Manhattan Bridge. The residential towers would be built above the commercial space.
Regarding the proposed zoning change, Mr. Whelan said his group had worked with city planners and the Economic Development Commission, and he expressed confidence that the floor-area ratio -- a measure of construction density -- of 3.5 along Livingston Street and 6.5 along Willoughby Street would be increased to the 12 that has been approved for the commercial district in Long Island City.
HE said many of the Brooklyn sites included in the proposal had been identified in previous studies as suitable for development. He said the large sites available on Willoughby Street would make it logical for commercial development, while the Livingston Street properties would be suitable for residential development because of their proximity to the Boerum Hill residential neighborhood.
Mr. Whelan said the proposal still faced an environmental and land use review before being submitted to the city's Planning Commission. As with all zoning changes, approval by the City Council is needed as well. He said he expected the process to be completed by the end of 2003.
A spokesman for Marty Markowitz, the new Brooklyn borough president, said Mr. Markowitz "cautiously supports" the change as long as emphasis is placed on public transportation to avoid having larger buildings add to passenger-vehicle traffic.
Developers say that while the proposed zoning change will not be enough by itself to spur development, it is an essential prerequisite. "Nothing will happen unless there is an up-zone," said Jane Marshall, a vice president of Forest City Ratner and project manager for Atlantic Terminal and 330 Jay Street, which is being built to house the Kings County Family Court and part of the New York Supreme Court. "You need to have the density to encourage development."
Joshua L. Muss, who is seeking to build a 280-room addition to his highly successful Marriott Hotel in downtown Brooklyn, said the city needs to encourage development in the boroughs because the process is so drawn out that it discourages most builders.
"We need to focus now on getting sites ready so we can act quickly when companies are ready" to sign leases, Mr. Muss said. "To do that, we need the support of the city and community groups."

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
Semigloss

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: VOORHEES 

 BODY:
IF New Jersey is the much-maligned stepchild among states, where does that leave South Jersey?
 Historically, people from the northern part of the state have been known to peer south and see nothing but hicks and the sticks. These days, however, others -- including at least one publisher -- see dollar bills. 
 "South Jersey has been bowing to North Jersey far too long, or basically, it has been ignored," said Mike Hogan, the director of advertising for SJ Magazine, a new monthly publication that was mailed to 113,000 homes earlier this month. 
Mr. Hogan -- the guiding light of the new venture -- said he saw an untapped high-demographic market in seven contiguous towns in Camden and Burlington Counties -- Voorhees, Cherry Hill, Haddonfield, Moorestown, Evesham, Mount Laurel and Medford.
Before turning his attention to SJ Magazine, Mr. Hogan had worked in sales management for CBS in Philadelphia, Chicago and New York, and had been sales manager for the Philadelphia 76ers basketball team and WIP-AM, the sports-talk radio station in Philadelphia. Though he has long lived in the Pennsylvania suburbs of Philadelphia, he has viewed the growth of high-end businesses in South Jersey with great interest.
"But there was nowhere for these people to advertise effectively," he said.
Mr. Hogan cited a stretch of car dealers along Route 73 in Burlington County. 
"They could go to Philadelphia Magazine and get their demographic, but they would be paying a lot for people in the western suburbs of Philadelphia who would never come to them," he said.
Or a jeweler. "If he wants to advertise a Rolex watch, he isn't likely to do it on local TV or a local newspaper," he said. "If he is in South Jersey, now he has a place to go."
The cover of the first magazine features Jeremy Roenick, a new Philadelphia Flyer and one of the magazine's 22 People to Watch in 2002 -- a tried-and-true device of regional magazines.
"That is no coincidence," said Mr. Hogan.
"The people at Philadelphia Magazine are pretty intelligent, and we intend to run with their game plan," he added. "We just want a different market. So we'll have people to watch in South Jersey and the best of South Jersey and so forth.
The links to Philadelphia Magazine -- one of the more successful of the country's slick regional monthlies -- run even deeper. Mr. Hogan tapped a former editor of Philadelphia Magazine, Maury Levy, who is now in the public relations business in South Jersey, to be editorial director of SJ Magazine.
"It seemed to make sense to me both editorially and in advertising," said Mr. Levy, who was director of new publications for Playboy before starting Levy Warren Marketing Media in Marlton. "Editorially, the otherwise local magazines pretty much covered South Jersey as an afterthought. Some of them, I noticed, even had the old area code, 609, in restaurant listings."
Turning conventional wisdom a bit on its ear, Mr. Levy said that the current recession might actually make this a good time to get businesses to advertise in a targeted publication like SJ Magazine.
"That jeweler may be cutting back a bit on his budget and, maybe, thinking about dropping TV," said Mr. Levy. "But if we can sell him this 113,000 families in upscale towns within a 30-minute drive of his store, we might be coming in at just the right time."
As for how much money investors have put up, Mr. Hogan would only say the amount was "substantial." And in these tight economic times, he said, "We think we have a success here" when the question was raised about just how long a ride he and his fellow investors were are in for.
Though the cover of SJ Magazine is glossy, its inside pages are on newsprint -- not quite a match for Philadelphia Magazine and New Jersey Monthly, which are all glossy. And while those magazines have a lot of soft features, they do often include investigative or critical articles. At this point, at least, SJ Magazine will not.
"I don't see us as the social conscience of South Jersey," Mr. Hogan said. "We aren't necessarily trying to right wrongs here, except insofar as South Jersey gets unfairly treated as opposed to North Jersey."
He pointed to a question-and-answer article featuring State Senator Diane Allen, a Republican from Burlington County, which quizzed her on how she was making South Jersey a priority in the Legislature.
Other articles in the 48-page first issue included a guide to wellness centers and health clubs in South Jersey, a story on Spirit Airlines and its service out of Atlantic City International Airport, a wine column and a restaurant guide. There is a price of $2.50 listed on the cover, but all 113,000 copies were mailed free to homes in the seven-town target area.
"When I came to South Jersey to live 30 years ago, there was a lot of open space and not much communal identity," Mr. Levy. "You lived in Haddonfield or Moorestown or whatever, and went to Philadelphia or New York. Now you eat well in Cherry Hill or you can buy a $580 pair of trousers at Hugo Boss in Mount Laurel. It is a different kind of place and people here identify with it."
"Now we complain about the traffic, which means we have a rich, growing community," he said with a chuckle.
For now, at least, Mr. Levy has put out the word: he wants short stories.
"I am not someone who says print is going away, but I admit I have less time to read newspapers and magazines than I used to," he said. "This will be something that stays around the house and you pick up for 10 minutes here and 15 minutes there to read something in it."
As for subject matter, Mr. Hogan said the publication would initially focus on the seven target towns before spreading out, particularly as people visit the seashore in the summer.
"We have to remember that we are here to localize advertising and content for people in this area, so we don't want to expand too quickly," he said. "But it is inevitable. South Jersey has been ignored and now, we feel, it is a pretty good place to be."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
A Fight to Restore Cleanup Money

BYLINE:  By KIRSTY SUCATO

 BODY:
TWICE a year, Fair Lawn holds a litter cleanup day. A posse of about 15 volunteers boards the township minivan. They pluck a surprising number of beer cans from the edges of a highway off-ramp and by evening fill a two-ton dump truck with detritus of the disposable economy. All it costs the township is some cotton gardening gloves, garbage bags, a driver and the lunch tab at the Heights Deli. 
 Every town in New Jersey sponsors some kind of antilitter program, and it is no coincidence. The state Department of Environmental Protection gives municipalities from $4,000 to $300,000 a year to spend on litter control efforts under the Clean Communities Grant Program. The 15-year-old program is financed by a tax on litter-producing industries and generates about $14 million a year for towns and counties. Recipients love it because it is like gravy at budget time. 
 "In the scope of Fair Lawn's budget, $4,300 doesn't seem like a lot of money," said Ron Lottermann, the town's coordinator of the Clean Communities program. "But the council would not be giving me $4,300 to be doing these programs." 
But in a move that has left local officials baffled and disheartened, the Republican leadership of the State Assembly effectively killed the program this month by failing to vote on a bill to reauthorize it. The bill made it through committees in both houses of the Legislature but was quietly pulled from the Assembly's voting agenda on Jan. 7. Observers blame election-year politics in a climate in which supporting taxes of any kind is grounds for excoriation. 
Towns have begun an intensive lobbying effort, flooding lawmakers with hundreds of letters and resolutions. 
"If the revenue is lost, residents of the state of New Jersey will be the losers," said Helen Yeldell, a legislative analyst for the New Jersey State League of Municipalities. "We see this as property-tax relief because without this revenue source, municipalities cannot sustain this program." 
Even industries that pay the tax are arguing for its return. 
"Good public policy gave way to pretty poor politics," said James C. Morford, the chairman of the New Jersey Food Council, a trade organization for supermarkets. "We need to restore the program and try to make it very clear that this isn't just raising taxes. It's restoring a program that was funded by the businesses that sell the products that wind up in the litter stream." 
The reauthorization bill's main opponent, Assemblyman Guy R. Gregg, Republican of Long Valley, acknowledged that politics were partly to blame. 
"The major debate was to tax or not to tax," he said. "A number of members who may believe they have close races in the future say, 'Why would I want to end my no-tax pledge on a $13 million program?' " 
But Mr. Gregg, who owns a restaurant in Chester, said he had long opposed the program on philosophical grounds. It is clumsy, outdated and difficult to enforce, he said. High-end restaurants pay the tax at the same rate as fast-food places even though they generate less litter. Tire manufacturers pay too, despite strict recycling regulations that help prevent tires from ending up being dumped illegally. He stressed that he supported the Clean Communities Program itself and had sponsored a bill that would appropriate $13.3 million from the state's general budget to pay for the program. 
"It ended up being an issue of do we have to continue archaic programs or do we have to start this again and fix it the right way?" he said. "It is an excellent program, yes. I'm not going to say it's bad. But it should fall in line with the rest of the grant programs that we do." 
Discussions of this type leave some local officials perplexed. 
"I don't understand it, to be honest with you," said Harry W. Elton Jr., the mayor of Woodbury Heights in Gloucester County. The town has donated Clean Communities money money to Scout troops and to the sixth-grade class fund at its elementary school in exchange for the students' working to collect litter. "It's obviously a win-win for everybody," Mr. Elton said. "If the prior administration felt funding had to go somewhere else or had a specific target for the funding so be it, but it just seems like the Legislature just left it die." 
Mr. Lottermann of Fair Lawn said he was disheartened. 
"There are a lot of people in my position as clean communities coordinators, and for them to just pull it out because they want to play games or something else sort of defeats what all of us have worked for," he said. "Can the town live without me giving stuff away to promote the antilitter program? Sure they can. But at some point it's going to come back. Somebody's going to have to pay for the cleanup when it is washed into the storm drains and ends up in streams and oceans." 
Among its Clean Communities programs, Pemberton Township hires an entertainer to teach schoolchildren the value of recycling. Thalia C. Kay, the mayor, said taxpayers would be hurt most. Pemberton Township has received as much as $43,000 under the program, equivalent to half a penny on its municipal tax rate. 
"When we have to replace the money, it's going to be given to the taxpayer to pay," Mayor Kay said. "It has to be picked up by someone because people still want the service." 
But for now, local officials will have to wait for the newly sworn Legislature to begin meeting Jan. 31. 
Governor James E. McGreevey has not taken a public stance on the issue. 
"The governor is a strong supporter of recycling," said Richard A. Lee, a spokesman. "If it gets to his desk, he'll have to review it and make a determination at that time." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The state has given Fair Lawn $4,300 a year for litter cleanup, but may stop. (Don Standing for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
Practice Makes Perfect (and Poorer Parents)

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
HAS so little changed since Allan Sherman, the late comedic songwriter, recorded these lyrics in 1966 (sung to "Makin' Whoopee")?
My daughter, Linda, she takes ballet.
Her first recital was yesterday.
 She dropped her tutu, her left shoe, too. 
 She needs more lessons.
Then there's my daughter, Dottie,
She takes guitar, that's true.
Junior, he takes karate.
Smashed her guitar in two.
For all these lessons, I have to pay.
I must raise money. I found a way.
Read my brochure folks, learn how to be poor, folks.
I'm giving lessons.
Parents seem to have been as crazed then about training their children as baby boomers are now.
My three sons, ages 7 to 11, play on community baseball and T-ball teams and once played organized soccer and basketball. They have taken trumpet lessons and chess classes.
My daughter, Marian, 14, has been a member of the Brownies, has played the violin and is now taking piano lessons. She has also joined the drama department and the choir at her high school, a step that means buying costumes and show tickets. This spring, the choir is taking a $400 field trip to Virginia. Before Thanksgiving, she announced that she wanted to try out for the highly competitive regional chorus. I encouraged her.
"But if I'm going to make it, I need to take voice lessons," she said.
That was $40 a week for several weeks, but she made the cut, and her concert this month was a delight.
That explains, of course, why we say yes to our children. We want them to find their passion -- and what if they really are talented and just need a bit of coaching? So even before they go off to college, we've spent a fortune on them.
Actually, we may be a bit more obsessed about this than our parents were. According to 2000 figures from the Agriculture Department, which tracks family expenditures, parents with incomes of $38,000 to $64,000 spent $18,510 on miscellaneous items for the average child from birth through the age of 18. That is up from $17,600 in 1960, adjusted for inflation. The category includes entertainment, reading material, VCR's, summer camp and lessons. A study by Child Trends, a nonpartisan research group in Washington, found that about 82 percent of American children had participated in at least one extracurricular activity in 1999.
One? How about five or six? Bugs Peterschmidt, 44, of Plymouth, Minn., said her two children were involved in piano, trumpet, soccer, scouting, after-school math classes, swimming and summer enrichment programs. She said she was spending about $3,000 a year on all the activities.
"I was working part time, and once one of my paychecks went to all of this stuff," she said. "The whole thing. I was bummed."
Susan Kakuk, 42, also of Plymouth, said she was also spending about $3,000 a year on her two children. Barbara Carlson, 53, of Greenfield, Minn., put the total for her four children at a few thousand dollars. Mark Lino, an economist for the Agriculture Department, said parents found ways to pay for all of this.
"People seem to be purchasing more of this for their children since 1960," he said. "I think it is one of the reasons more women have joined the work force. Parents are also cutting back expenditures on themselves. They are not cutting back on their children; they are spending more on their children."
Kristin A. Moore, the president of Child Trends, said that there was a downside to all this. "They are good for children until you get past the midpoint and everyone is overwhelmed by the sheer quantity," she said. "At some point families can get too busy, but no one knows how much is too much."
SOME families know. Ms. Kakuk, Ms. Carlson and Ms. Peterschmidt all decided to slow down their children, asking them to drop some activities. They didn't cut back for economic reasons, but to have more time together as a family.
"Some families are taking like a sabbatical, not signing up for anything," Ms. Carlson said. "They are spending time together instead, like getting together and visiting grandparents. Before, they couldn't go because they had tournaments and competitions."
Ms. Kakuk goes over each activity with her children. "We look at the time commitments and see how that affects the family," she said. "My daughter wanted to be in competitive dance, but it was three to four nights a week and weekend competitions. We asked, 'How is this going to affect the family?' It was not just driving her there. There would be nobody home to help her brother with his schoolwork, and we wouldn't have dinner together. She really recognized that it isn't just her."
Now Ms. Kakuk's family has a special family night one day a week. They rotate the cooking chores (cheese sandwiches and canned pears were one child's menu), use the good china and spend the night hanging out together, doing things like playing games and reading.
"It's gotten to the point that if one of the kids gets an invitation, they say: 'No, I can't. That's family night,' " Ms. Kakuk said. "A year and a half ago they would have pleaded, 'Can I go?' Now they don't even question it. They value it so much."
Which shows that some financial issues are not about money at all.

HEADLINE: BENEFITS 

 BODY:
 Building From the Mind Up

WEDNESDAY -- Gov. George E. Pataki is to speak about the role of universities in rebuilding downtown at a dinner at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers to aid New School University programs and its scholarship fund for those affected by the Sept. 11 attacks. Felix Rohatyn will be honored. Cocktails at 6:30 will be followed by dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 229-5958.

Thurman Munson Awards

THURSDAY -- Joe Torre, Don Mattingly and Robin Ventura are among the sports figures who will be honored at a dinner at the New York Marriott Marquis to aid the Association for the Help of Retarded Children. HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA; 
Fight Heats Up Again Over Grassy Bed of Rails

BYLINE:  By KELLY CROW

 BODY:
There has long been a hobo serenity to the High Line, an elevated rail bed with grassy patches and rusting tracks that snakes above 10th Avenue between 34th and Gansevoort Streets. Built in the 1930's to carry freight and unused since 1980, the High Line and its peaceful views reveal little of the decade-long fight over its fate.
 The latest battle started last month when Justice David B. Saxe of State Supreme Court lifted an order that had prevented the city and a group of Chelsea property owners from tearing down the structure, which they consider an unsafe eyesore. Others want to renovate the strip as a park. 
 "This is a terrific win for us," said Michael Lefkowitz, a lawyer for Edison Properties, one of 19 businesses that own land beneath the High Line. 
Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the city's Economic Development Corporation, said an agreement to share the $11 million cost of dismantling the High Line was being circulated among the property owners and the rail bed's owner, CSX, of Richmond, Va. "It's about eliminating a public safety hazard," Ms. Patterson said, "but it's also about enabling the city to move forward and better develop the area."
Half the property owners have signed the agreement, she said. The city and CSX have not done so. A CSX spokesman, Robert Sullivan, said the company would not sign until everyone else had. If all parties sign, a 120-day waiting period is then required.
Robert Hammond, co-founder of a group called Friends of the High Line, hopes supporters have enough time to save it. A ruling is expected next month in a lawsuit the group has filed against the city, claiming the demolition plans violate the city's land-use review process. And on Feb. 6, the group is to release a study by the Design Trust for Public Space that gives ideas for raising $40 million and renovating the High Line as a park promenade. Advance galleys of the study were made available last week.
In a foreword to the study, written before he became mayor, Mr. Bloomberg said: "Today, on the West Side of Manhattan, we have an opportunity to create a great new public promenade on top of an out-of-use elevated rail viaduct called the High Line. This would provide much-needed green space for residents and visitors, and it would attract new businesses and residents, strengthing our economy. We know it can work . . . . I look forward to working with Friends of the High Line and other interested parties to develop a feasible reuse scenario." 
Former Mayor Giuliani favored demolition.
Last Friday, a mayoral spokeswoman said Mr. Bloomberg was still familiarizing himself with the issues. Daniel L. Doctoroff, deputy mayor for economic development, met Friday with Friends of the High Line.
"It's disappointing to see all this last-minute political maneuvering," Mr. Hammond said. "But we've still got a good case, and we're cautiously optimistic." KELLY CROW

GRAPHIC: Photo: The High Line, unused since 1980, snakes above 10th Avenue. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times) Map of Manhattan highlighting High Line.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
The Rise of the Fee-Based Account

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
TERRY SANTINI sold almost 1,000 shares of stock from a traditional brokerage account last Tuesday, switching the proceeds into a professionally managed account. She'll now pay a 1.875 percent annual fee on the assets instead of a commission for each transaction.
 "When you have a good broker, she'll invest for your interest" rather than to generate a commission for herself, said Ms. Santini, an accountant in Davie, Fla., and one of a growing number of investors who find fee-based accounts appealing. 
 Although the trend reflects a Wall Street strategy to produce a steadier stream of revenue, some investors welcome the chance to pay fixed fees for a bundle of services, including buying and selling stocks and bonds. 
"They're looking to the fee-based side more than I've ever seen," said Darran Blake, Ms. Santini's investment adviser at Salomon Smith Barney, noting that nearly 40 percent of her business is in fee-based accounts, versus scarcely any in the mid-1990's. Ms. Santini has some of each kind. Neither she nor Ms. Santini would disclose the actual commissions she pays in her traditional accounts, though the one for the trade last week was less than $100.
Fee-based accounts, also known as asset-based accounts, are not for everyone. Investors whose portfolios contain bonds or mutual funds that remain undisturbed might not find them worth the money.
And someone who regards commission-free trading in a fee-based account as a license to become a hyperactive day trader will no doubt find practical limits to the privilege. Morgan Stanley, for example, warns customers that it reserves the right to cancel fee-based accounts if trading exceeds an unspecified range.
Nonetheless, there is no denying the appeal of fee-based accounts on principle. Many investors and brokers say fee-based structures largely align the interests of both parties. The broker, collecting a percentage of assets in the account, benefits most when the investor makes money, not when the investor can be persuaded to make a trade. Accounts managed on the premises by local brokers typically cost about 1 percent, while those run at a brokerage firm's headquarters or by outside money managers may cost up to 2 percent.
"We never want a client to question our advice by wondering what our motives were," said Peggy Ruhlin, a principal at Budros & Ruhlin, a fee-only financial planning and investment advisory firm in Columbus, Ohio.
Not surprisingly, larger investors get lower rates in asset-based accounts, as they do when charges are levied by the transaction. Comparisons are difficult because commissions are typically negotiated downward from a standard that itself is imprecise. A Merrill Lynch broker, for example, quoted a commission range of 1 to 2 percent of the value of a trade but added that it could be less than 1 percent for large transactions by active clients. And the bigger your account, the more hand-holding and other personal attention you can command. For those willing to forgo such amenities, Merrill charges as little as $29.95 for online trades, and other online brokers may charge even less.
FOR years, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the chief industry regulator, has advocated fee-based accounts for some investors. In 1995, the commission published a report by a panel appointed by Arthur Levitt Jr., then the S.E.C. chairman, urging fundamental changes in the way brokers are compensated. Included was a recommendation that at least a portion of pay be based on the amount of client assets managed, thereby curbing the incentive to "churn" accounts for no sound financial reason. The panel did not suggest appropriate percentages for fees.
"I have long been concerned that the industry's compensation practices may exaggerate the conflicts of interest between a broker and investor -- conflicts that may ultimately compromise the advice an investor receives," Mr. Levitt said then.
The five-member panel, headed by Daniel P. Tully, then chairman of Merrill Lynch, also urged firms to stop paying brokers more for peddling particular products or favoring in-house products. Moreover, it said they should avoid contests among employees and paying up-front recruitment bonuses for brokers who take customers loyal to them from firm to firm. 
Ms. Ruhlin said she did not know "how many Rolex watches and trips to Hawaii" she could have received by selling mutual funds if her company had not been fee-only.
The panel's recommendations were not binding, but some have taken hold.
Still, many investors will not benefit from accounts that require them to pay a percentage of assets, which can come to $2,000 a year or more on a $100,000 account. And if managed by others, the account may receive only "cloned" stock selection and little attention to tax consequences.
"Many times, a transaction account is the best," acknowledged Debra Jorgensen, a financial analyst and adviser in the San Francisco office of Merrill Lynch. "If it's cheaper, that's where we keep them."
One of Merrill's fee-based accounts is called Unlimited Advantage, which carries an annual charge for equities of 0.75 percent to 1.5 percent of assets, collected quarterly, and about 0.3 percent for bonds. Investment decisions are made by the investor, the broker or both.
Another account is Consults, run by money managers outside Merrill Lynch. It costs 0.85 percent to 2 percent for stocks and 0.6 percent to 1 percent for bonds, according to Ms. Jorgensen. Investors need $100,000 to qualify for either account.
One of the most aggressive promoters of fee-based accounts is UBS PaineWebber. As the year began, it started to charge its brokers a $12 fee for trades in accounts based on transactions, while paying them a bonus for fee-based transactions. Some brokers have objected, contending that fee-based accounts are inappropriate for many customers who make few trades. UBS PaineWebber also halted a longstanding practice in which brokers could cut commissions on transactions for clients, usually absorbing some of the discount themselves. 
Paul Marrone, a spokesman for PaineWebber, said brokers have been explaining the various accounts to clients. "Increasingly, clients are choosing fees as a way to pay for services," he said.
Many investors who are moving toward fee-based accounts were previously do-it-yourselfers when it came to investing. But two years of stock market declines have changed their approach. "A lot of people got hurt and now say they're too old or too tired and don't want the responsibility," said Ms. Blake of Salomon Smith Barney. "Everyone was a winner" for years, she added, but now "they're willing to pay a fee."
AT Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, a popular fee-based account is called Choice, which has a $50,000 minimum and costs 2.25 percent a year for the first $100,000 in stocks and 1 percent for mutual funds, bonds, variable annuities and even cash. The fee is at least $1,000 a year. The firm promises "virtually unlimited" commission-free trading, but there can be heavy penalties for closing the account.
Still, a fee-based account does not eliminate the possibility of a conflict between the interests of a broker and a customer.
While investors can be sure that a broker is not recommending the purchase of stock for the sake of a commission, they may not be clear about the motivation for advice that would affect the account's asset size, Ms. Ruhlin said.
"If a customer calls and says he decided to pay off the mortgage, he may wonder why I advise him not to," Ms. Ruhlin said. "To remove all conflict of interest is, I think, an impossibility."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KEW GARDENS; 
A Borough President's Goal: Dethroning the Queen of Queens

BYLINE:  By E. E. LIPPINCOTT

 BODY:
The note that sounded the end of her reign was quiet. Without pomp or circumstance, the new Queens borough president said that, as part of a redecoration of Borough Hall, a large mural featuring a portrait of Queen Catherine of Braganza would be removed.
 Catherine was no ordinary royal: married to King Charles II of England, she was a Portuguese princess whose family benefited from the slave trade and persecuted Jews in Europe. The borough was supposedly named for her. 
 Her portrait was one of a number of stained and battered murals installed by the administration of Donald Manes in the 1970's. Some were street scenes painted by children. But the section with Catherine contained professionally rendered highlights of the borough's history. The murals will be removed soon. Helen Marshall, the borough president, says she is not sorry to lose Catherine.
"When so many people are offended by something, I have to listen to my community," said Ms. Marshall, who is the daughter of Guyanese immigrants. "Catherine represents a dark past."
Behind the planned removal is a widespread, if contested, belief that Brooklyn, or Kings County, is named for Charles II and that Catherine, his wife, served the same role for Queens. Historians say these stories are unproven, but many residents of Queens say that, regardless, Catherine should not be a symbol of a borough that bubbles with cultural diversity.
Others disagreed, and the debate reached a height a few years ago when the Portuguese government proposed to help erect a statue of Catherine at Hunters Point, opposite the United Nations. Social activists, historians and others fought the project, which withered under the opposition. But there is little resistance to the dethroning of the portrait, and Ms. Marshall gave a reason. "Ninety percent of the people here didn't know who it was," she said. 
As for her redecoration of Borough Hall, Ms. Marshall says she's trying to be economical; perhaps a lick of paint and some cabinets and wall space for rotating exhibitions.
Jim Driscoll, vice president for history at the Queens Historical Society, won't miss the portrait either. 
"I never really understood the Catherine-Queens connection," he said. "She probably didn't even know Queens existed." E. E. LIPPINCOTT

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Enron's Way: Pay Packages Foster Spin, Not Results

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
AS the stock plummeted, investors and employees alike were left with big losses. But one group of shareholders came out ahead -- management. Many board members and top executives managed to sell millions of dollars of shares before the big fall and still have something to show for the stock's once-lofty price.
 This is the story of Enron, of course, but it hardly ends there. Over the last two years, as the stock market has fallen about 30 percent from its peak, the description fits dozens of other companies as well. 
 For example, Roger G. Ackerman, the former chairman of Corning, sold $14 million of the company's stock last year, mostly when it was trading at about $57 a share, or seven times its current price. Donald R. Scifres, the co-chairman of JDS Uniphase, made $23 million selling company shares last year; the stock has lost nearly 90 percent of its value since January 2001. David R. Alvarez sold $14 million worth of stock in Providian Financial, where he is vice chairman, last year before the company acknowledged that its balance sheet wasn't quite what it was cracked up to be. The stock, which traded at $60 a share last summer, now trades at around $4.
Some of the biggest paydays have come at obscure companies that were once market darlings. John J. Moores, better known as the owner of the San Diego Padres baseball team, made $101 million last year selling shares of Peregrine Systems, on whose board he serves, before its shares fell by more than two-thirds. Richard Aube, a director at Capstone Turbine, made $51 million selling its stock last year, according to Thomson Financial. If you bought when he sold at around $30 a share, your investment would be showing an 80 percent loss now.
The contrast is obviously cringe-inducing. But it is more than that. Even when executives simply fail to live up to their own predictions -- rather than break the law, as some people suspect that Enron managers did -- the big insider paydays offer a good lesson in how economic incentives are askew in corporate America. 
Corporate spin aside, executives do not always prosper most by making their companies great. They can often profit more from creating unrealistic expectations than from delivering consistently impressive results.
Consider two companies. One has a stock price that has appreciated slowly, starting at $20 five years ago and gaining $2 a year, to $30 today. The second company's stock also started at $20 five years ago, then zoomed to $100 after a few years but has since fallen back to $20.
By any reasonable measure, the leaders of the first company have done a better job. Their share price has grown 50 percent, and they have avoided making grandiose predictions that cause Wall Street analysts to set silly targets. The second company has a stock that has underperformed a savings account over the long run, and scores of workers and investors have been burned by false hopes.
Yet if the top executives of both companies had received similar amounts of stock and both sold their shares on a regular schedule, the executives of the second company would actually be ahead. They would have made so much money selling the stock when it was trading near $100 that they would be multimillionaires despite the humbling decline.
THIS is the Enron model of pay for performance, and it has become common. Executives receive enormous grants of stock or options, saying they are simply aligning their own interests with those of their shareholders. But the packages are so generous that even a temporary rise in the share price, accompanied by the sale of a portion of an executive's stock, can leave him set for life. The appeal of overly aggressive accounting methods and manipulated earnings becomes obvious.
"You're providing C.E.O.'s with a perverse incentive," said Nell Minow, the editor of the Corporate Library, a research firm in Washington. "You're rewarding them for a goal that is not in the interest of long-term shareholders."
The executives who have made millions of dollars selling once-expensive shares say they have done nothing wrong. They simply followed a regular, legal schedule of selling stock, they say, and would be far richer if the stock price had not dropped.
All of that is usually true. But it is also true that when an economic system richly rewards certain behavior, no one should be surprised when that behavior becomes the norm. If you want to change it, you have to change the incentives. The Enron mess has the potential to focus people's attention on the complicated task of doing precisely that.
