HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bush Defends His Refusal To Reveal Enron Contacts
President Bush defended his refusal to turn over information to Congress about contacts between Enron and the administration's energy task force, saying the request was "an encroachment on the executive branch's ability to conduct business."
 The president's comments makes a constitutional showdown all but inevitable between the White House and the General Accounting Office, an investigative agency of Congress. Page A1. 

Global Crossing Files for Bankruptcy
Global Crossing, which spent five years and $15 billion to build a worldwide network of high-speed Internet and telephone lines, filed for bankruptcy protection, unable to find enough customers to make its network profitable. It has $22.4 billion of assets and $12.4 billion of debt, making its filing the largest by a telecommunications company. A1.

Top Level Shake-up at Conde Nast
In the first top-level shake-up of the year at a major magazine company, Peter King Hunsinger, the most senior marketing executive at Conde Nast Publications, is leaving. He will be succeeded by Richard D. Beckman, vice president and publisher of Vogue magazine, left. Thomas A. Florio, vice president and publisher at GQ since 1999, will succeed Mr. Beckman. For now, the GQ position is vacant, but some speculate the post may go to Ronald A. Galotti, former publisher of Vogue. C8.

Jenny Craig Is Sold for $115 Million
A group of investors led by ACI Capital Company and DB Capital Partners, an investment wing of Deutsche Bank, announced it would buy the weight-loss chain Jenny Craig, paying $115 million, or $5.30 for each share of Jenny Craig, a 68 premium over its trading price last Friday and significantly more than the stock has been worth in the last two years. C4.

Big Securities Firms Plan Moves
Morgan Stanley, the largest securities company firm in Manhattan, has agreed to buy the former 107-acre Texaco headquarters in Westchester County as part of an effort to decentralize its operations. At the same time, Goldman, Sachs is planning to move its equity trading department to Jersey City. A1.

Last-Minute Buying Lifts Stocks
A burst of last-minute bargain hunting gave the market a modest gain. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 25.67 points, or 0.3 percent, at 9,865.75. The Nasdaq composite index rose 6.21 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,943.91, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.22 points, to 1,133.06. C11.

2001 New-Home Sales Set Record
Sales of new homes rose 5.7 percent in December and set a record for the year, the government said, as the housing sector registered a stunning performance despite the economic recession. New homes sold last month at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 946,000, up from a revised 895,000 pace in November, the Commerce Department said. Analysts had expected a 1 percent decline. C11.

Apple Breaks the Gigahertz Mark
For the first time, Apple Computer broke the 1 gigahertz mark in single-processor performance in its computers, introducing a high-end desktop system priced at $2,999. Also, it said the order rate for its novel flat-panel-display iMac G4 is a record. C11.

Disagreements at World Trade Talks
A new global round of trade talks convened at the World Trade Organization's headquarters in Geneva, and almost immediately, squabbles broke out that threatened to undermine the negotiations. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Beware The Yikes Of March

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
IT was not officially exam period at New York University, but Prof. Anders Henriksson was busy yesterday giving a history test at a campus deli. He was expecting the worst.
 Dr. Henriksson, a professor of history at Shepherd College in West Virginia, is the compiler of "Non Campus Mentis" (Workman Publishing), which is a history of the world taken verbatim from term papers and exams at American and Canadian colleges. In this chronicle from the Stoned Age to the Berlin Mall, Judyism is a monolithic religion with the god Yahoo. Gothic cathedrals are supported by flying buttocks. Hitler terrorizes enemies with his Gespacho. Caesar is assassinated on the Yikes of March and declares, "Me too, Brutus!" 
 How widespread is this ignorance? Dr. Henriksson demonstrated by giving a 27-question quiz, with 16 needed to get a passing grade (roughly 60 percent): 
In one sentence or less, identify Winston Churchill, Otto von Bismarck, Mohandas Gandhi, Nikita Khrushchev, Benito Mussolini, Sigmund Freud, Florence Nightingale and Adam Smith. In what countries are Warsaw, Caracas, Antwerp, Shanghai, Lagos and Pearl Harbor?
In what year did the United States Civil War end? World War I? When was the Russian Revolution? When did World War II start? When did American women get the right to vote in national elections? When was Napoleon defeated at Waterloo? When did Hitler become German chancellor? 
Find an error in each of these excerpts from student essays contained in Dr. Henriksson's book: 
*"Martin Luther Junior's famous 'If I Had a Hammer' speech." 
*"John F. Kennedy worked closely with the Russians to solve the Canadian Missile Crisis."
*"Stalin, Roosevelt, Churchill and Truman were known as the 'Big Three.' "
*"Athena the Hun rampaged the Balkans as far as France."
*"Ferdinand and Isabella conquered Granola, a part of Spain now known as Mexico."
*"Good times ended when England suffered civil war between the Musketeers and the Round Ones." 
The quiz was taken by five male and five female N.Y.U. undergraduates, chosen unscientifically by me at the Campus Eatery, a deli on West Fourth Street. Dr. Hendriksson graded leniently, but only one of the 10 students passed, and just barely with a 17. The average grade was 10 of 27. They all knew who Freud was, but that was about the extent of their common knowledge. 
A freshman economics major identified Adam Smith as an American president, and Florence Nightingale as a knight. A junior history major called the nurse a "famous poet" and located Caracas in Ohio.
A junior majoring in politics said the English civil war pitted the Round Ones against the "Square Ones." (It was the Roundheads versus the Cavaliers.) Other students placed Athena the Hun's rampage in the Spanish and the Austrian parts of the Balkans. Granola was called a part of Spain now known as "Florence."
The dates, not surprisingly, proved trouble for everyone. One student put the Civil War's end in 1770 instead of 1865. The Russian Revolution was moved to 1850 (the correct answer was any year from 1917 to 1920). Only one student knew that World War I ended in 1918, and only two knew the next world war started in 1939. No one put Waterloo in 1815, women's suffrage in 1920 or Hitler's rise in 1933.
You could interpet these results as a rebuke to American education, but the one foreign student in the group -- a German sophomore majoring in business -- flunked, too. He placed Warsaw in Austria. 
Dr. Hendriksson was neither surprised nor indignant at the results. "I'm not trying to launch a jeremiad against the American school system," he said. "But I do want to show that the base of common knowledge isn't as wide as we commonly assume. Our culture doesn't put a high emphasis on history."
But at least we sometimes recognize the limits of our knowledge. "I love it in student essays when they know they're going astray," Dr. Henriksson said. "They start trying to get philosophical about lack of knowledge, and they just get into more trouble." He paused and quoted one such philosopher. 
"Thus has our stream of consciousness developed a waterfall," Dr. Henriksson said, smiling as he savored the student's wisdom. Then he opened his book and fondly read its concluding rumination from a student essayist:
"It is now the age of now. This concept grinds our critical, seething minds to a halt."
Me too, Brutus!

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE OLYMPICS; 
U.S. IS REQUESTING TIGHTER SECURITY AT UTAH OLYMPICS

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 

 BODY:
The Justice Department has requested major last-minute changes in security arrangements at the Olympic Games in Salt Lake City out of concern that some sites had not been adequately protected from a terrorist attack, law enforcement officials said.
 The department's move came after Attorney General John Ashcroft visited Salt Lake City earlier this month and came away dissatisfied with security plans for parts of the city away from the sports arenas, officials said. 
 They said Mr. Ashcroft was concerned that terrorists might take advantage of what he saw as inadequate security in open-air areas of shops and restaurants in Salt Lake City and surrounding communities where crowds would gather before and after the sporting events, which start on Feb. 8. In response, Olympics organizers have promised to increase surveillance and the size of their security patrols. 
Federal law enforcement agencies say they are intimately involved in security preparations for two other huge public events over the next two weeks: the World Economic Forum in New York, which will draw government and business leaders from around the world to Manhattan beginning Thursday, and the Super Bowl this Sunday in New Orleans.
Almost 4,000 police officers, backed up by hundreds of agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, have been assigned this week to surround the Waldorf-Astoria hotel, the site of the Economic Forum. Page B1. 
The security arrangements are expected to be nearly as exhaustive at the Super Bowl, which is the first sporting event ever to be designated a National Security Special Event by the White House. Page D1. 
But Justice Department officials said that in terms of security preparations, neither the World Economic Forum nor the Super Bowl could compare with the Olympic Games, which have been a terrorist target in past years and which will take place this winter over a 900-square-mile area of Utah -- much of it mountainous and snow-covered -- over 17 days.
Of the three events, officials said, the Olympics were of the greatest concern to Mr. Ashcroft, which explained why he conducted an unusually detailed, venue-by-venue inspection tour in Salt Lake City over four days this month. They said he had not been similarly involved in security planning for the World Economic Forum or the Super Bowl.
President Bush is expected to attend the opening ceremony of the Olympics on Feb. 8.
At the time of Mr. Ashcroft's visit to Utah, the attorney general said the level of Olympics security preparations would "set a new standard." A few days earlier, Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, said Olympic organizers and security officials were doing "everything they can to minimize the risk."
Officials said today that while Mr. Ashcroft and Mr. Ridge agreed that overall security precautions were the best ever seen for an Olympics, the Justice Department still believed that much more needed to be done in Utah, especially to protect against the possibility of a terrorist attack at a site away from the athletic venues.
At the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta, one person was killed and more than 100 people were injured when a pipe bomb exploded in an entertainment area known as Centennial Park, which was away from the sports arenas where competitions were held. 
A spokesman for Mr. Ridge said that the homeland security director had been pleased by coordination among federal, state and local agencies planning for the Games in Salt Lake City and that he, unlike Mr. Ashcroft, had not been asked to focus on the details of some of the security preparations. The federal government is expected to spend at least $250 million for security in Salt Lake City, a record for an Olympics held in the United States.
Robert Flowers, the head of the umbrella organization responsible for security in Salt Lake City, confirmed in a telephone interview from Utah that the Justice Department had requested a series of last-minute security changes after Mr. Ashcroft's visit.
Mr. Flowers said the Olympics committee was "really close" to satisfying most of the attorney general's requests, many of them involving the deployment of additional security officers to areas where large numbers of people would gather away from the sports arenas. 
"It's about more officers, more bodies," said Mr. Flowers, who declined to discuss other, specific changes in the security plans.
Law enforcement officials said that as a result of his trip, Mr. Ashcroft had also ordered a series of drills between local and federal law enforcement agencies to be certain that the government was prepared to respond to a terrorist attack or other emergency.
They said that elsewhere in the Justice Department, officials had ordered closer monitoring of domestic extremists, including abortion opponents and antigovernment groups, that are based in the Western mountain states surrounding Utah.
The authorities have accused an abortion opponent from North Carolina, Eric Rudolph, of the 1996 Atlanta bombing. Mr. Rudolph, who has also been tied to white-supremacist groups, remains a fugitive.
"The Justice Department is reminding everyone that our terrorist threat goes beyond Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda," a senior federal law enforcement official said. "There are domestic threats as well. I think it's fair to say we'd like more of everything, from uniformed people on the ground to sniffer dogs to surveillance cameras."
Justice Department officials said there was no surprise in Mr. Ashcroft's decision to become involved in many of the detailed security preparations for the Olympics.
"Since Sept. 11, counterterrorism has dominated his agenda, and he sees the Olympics as the biggest security headache we face right now," a department official said.
Despite his public praise for the preparations while in Salt Lake City, officials said, the attorney general returned to Washington to say he had uncovered a variety of "blind spots" in the security preparations that he felt needed immediate correction.
Mr. Flowers, the security coordinator in Salt Lake City, said that in meetings with Mr. Ashcroft there and in later conversations with the Justice Department, he had obtained a pledge for additional federal resources to beef up security.
He said that as a result of Mr. Ashcroft's recommendations, he had also received verbal assurances from local Olympics planners in Salt Lake City that they would free up more money for security. He would not say how much.
"We haven't had all the resources that we've needed to cover every base," he acknowledged, citing in particular the problem of paying for tightened security patrols in neighborhoods of Salt Lake City and surrounding communities that are not directly involved in the Olympics. "We can't put a fence completely around the state of Utah."
Law enforcement officials said there would be extraordinarily close communication between local and federal law enforcement officers, and between Salt Lake City and Washington.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is planning a 24-hour-a-day direct video hookup between the Olympics security command center in Salt Lake City and the F.B.I.'s Strategic Information Operations Center, allowing bureau officials in Washington to monitor hundreds of surveillance cameras that have been stationed around the Olympic sites.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mitt Romney, left, president of the organizing committee for the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, guided Attorney General John Ashcroft on a tour of venues on Jan. 19. Mr. Ashcroft praised preparations at the time. (Associated Press)(pg. A13)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: DIPLOMACY; 
Bush Offers Afghanistan U.S. Help for Training Of Military and Police

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 

 BODY:
With Afghanistan's interim leader, Hamid Karzai, at his side, President Bush vowed today to build "a lasting partnership" with the war-torn nation, by helping it to train its own police force and military and offering $50 million in credit for private investments in addition to the hundreds of millions of dollars of direct aid already pledged.
 "We will help the new Afghan government provide the security that is the foundation for peace," Mr. Bush told Mr. Karzai at a joint news conference in the White House Rose Garden after a meeting with senior national security officials. "The United States will continue to be a friend to the Afghan people in all the challenges that lie ahead." 
 But Mr. Bush and his top aides again made it plain that the administration had ruled out a direct military role for United States troops in an international peacekeeping force in Afghanistan. Mr. Karzai has broached the subject again on his first visit to Washington since taking power on Dec. 22, and the first visit by an Afghan head of state since 1963.
"Better yet than peacekeepers, which will be there for a while, with our help, let's have Afghanistan have her own military," Mr. Bush said. In the short term, the president said, American troops would continue their efforts to rout out Taliban and Al Qaeda elements and to provide logistical, intelligence and emergency assistance to the peacekeeping forces -- now mostly British -- on the ground.
For his part, Mr. Karzai, resplendent in his trademark green silk robe and gray lamb's-wool hat, declared: "This joint struggle against terrorism should go to the absolute end of it. We must finish them. We must bring them out of their caves and their hide-outs, and we promise to do that."
Mr. Karzai said his administration was assisting in the hunt for Osama bin Laden. 
"He is a fugitive," Mr. Karzai said in his clipped English. "If we find him, we'll catch him."
The meeting today was mostly symbolic, on a visit that Mr. Karzai himself has described as a sentimental trip to thank the United States for its military defeat of the Taliban. Senior administration officials said the half-hour meeting in the Oval Office, also attended by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, broke little policy ground, but allowed both leaders to restate their previously known positions on peacekeeping troops, for example.
At an international conference in Tokyo last week, the United States pledged almost $300 million in direct aid over the next year to help Afghanistan rebuild its shattered roads, schools, health care system and agricultural economy, part of a $1.8 billion first-year international commitment. A White House communique issued today spelled out various specifics, including a commitment to print and distribute nearly 10 million reading, mathematics and science textbooks in time for the beginning of the Afghan school year in March.
The separate $50 million line of credit from the government's Overseas Private Investment Corporation, announced today by Mr. Bush, is intended to function as risk insurance for private American companies that want to make commercial investments in Afghanistan.
With reports that Iran may be seeking to exert influence in the western areas of Afghanistan, an administration official would say only that Mr. Bush and Mr. Karzai discussed "regional issues" in their meeting.
While Afghanistan availed itself of American military training assistance as long ago as the 1950's, as Mr. Karzai noted today, Mr. Bush said his administration's commitment to help train a new Afghan army was "a significant change of policy." Washington has gone out of its way not to look too heavy-handed in its dealings with Mr. Karzai, whose hold on his sprawling, factionalized country is tenuous at best, and set to expire in five months.
By pledging such support today, one senior administration official said, Mr. Bush was sending a strong signal of American resolve.
"The messenger was almost as important as the message here, that you're hearing this from the president of the United States, and in public," the official said.
Before heading to the White House, where he lunched with Vice President Dick Cheney, Mr. Karzai helped raise the Afghan flag at his country's former embassy in the Kalorama neighborhood. The embassy had been padlocked since the Taliban took power in 1996.
"It has interior waterfalls, and it's not a Hyatt," said Tom Lauria, an embassy spokesman.
In a sign of the challenges Afghanistan faces, the flag of broad bars of black, red and green -- based on a 1964 design not used since Mohammad Zahir Shah was deposed nearly 30 years ago -- was sewn just this morning by two Afghan-American women in suburban Virginia.
"Let's hope this flag will be there forever and that the partnership between the American and Afghan people will be forever," Mr. Karzai said.
But moments after it began to flutter in the morning breeze, the flag was lowered and quickly taken to the White House. Officials explained that the design had just been approved by the interim government and that the flag, the only copy in town, was needed for the Rose Garden ceremony.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hamid Karzai, the interim Afghan leader, and President Bush yesterday at the White House, where they held a meeting and a news conference. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Up 2%; Hint of Revival 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods rose in December, the Commerce Department reported today, the second increase in the last three months and a sign that factories are starting to recover from a year-and-a-half-long slump.
 Orders for big-ticket goods increased 2 percent, to $176.4 billion, in contrast to a revised 6 percent decline the previous month. 
 Demand increased 3.5 percent for autos, aircraft, semiconductors and machinery after falling 20 percent in November. Orders for durable goods other than transportation equipment rose 1.4 percent in December compared with a revised 0.7 percent the previous month.
Another report by the Conference Board, a business research group, showed that a measure of consumer confidence in January was the highest in five months. The index of consumer sentiment rose to 97.3 this month from 94.6 in December. An index of expectations, which measures the outlook six months from now, soared to a one-year high.
"Expectations have come roaring back," said Tim Rogers, chief economist at Briefing.com in Boston. "It seems like the U.S. consumer is ready to go shop again."
Inventories had contracted by $61.9 billion at an annual pace in the third quarter, when the economy shrank at a 1.3 percent annual pace, according to official figures. Analysts said they probably fell more in the fourth quarter, suggesting that manufacturers would start increasing production to meet demand. 
Analysts had expected December durable goods orders to rise 1.4 percent, to $177.9 billion. They also expected a 1.4 percent rise, excluding transportation equipment.
Durable goods are products like aircraft and cars made to last more than three years. For 2001, orders fell 13.2 percent, in contrast to a 6.7 percent increase in 2000, the Commerce Department said. The decline last year was the worst showing since the current system of keeping records began in 1992.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Worries of More Enrons to Come Give Stock Prices a Pounding

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Concerns about the troubling practices that led to the failure of Enron slammed into the stock market yesterday.
 Companies whose shares took the worst beating were those with opaque or complex financial statements, those heavy with debt or those with even a whiff of off-balance-sheet obligations. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 247.51 points, to 9,618.24, a loss of 2.5 percent. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.86 percent of its value, dropping to 1,100.64. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.6 percent, to 1,892.99. 
 "It's the cockroach theory," said Anthony M. Maramarco, portfolio manager at the Babson Value Fund in Cambridge, Mass. "There's never going to be just one company that because of accounting practices or excessive debt levels will be a problem. As a result, we go out there and wholesale get rid of anything that might come close to being as tainted as what we have identified as the initial culprit."
Shares of financial companies fell across the board. Stocks of companies with troubling news, including PNC Financial and Tyco International, plunged even more than most.
"I think what Enron has raised is the question about all financial reporting," said Liz Miller, portfolio manager at Trevor Stewart Burton & Jacobsen, in New York. "The detail of the reporting, the clarity of the reporting, the simplicity of the reporting." 
Ms. Miller said it was no coincidence that stocks took a pounding just ahead of President Bush's State of the Union address and on the first day of a two-day meeting by the Federal Reserve Board. "I think investors are looking for some very high-level responses to this condition," she said.
Selling was widespread yesterday for bank and financial services stocks, which have made billions in loans to companies now viewed as far riskier than they were when the nation's economy was healthy. Shares of J. P. Morgan Chase lost 6.6 percent of their value, Merrill Lynch fell 7.5 percent, and Citigroup shed 5.3 percent. 
Telecommunications companies were hammered after Global Crossing, a giant concern, filed for bankruptcy. WorldCom, the big long-distance carrier based in Clinton, Miss., plunged to $10.40, its lowest level since 1995. And the Williams Companies, a natural gas pipeline company, fell 22 percent on disclosures that it might have $2.4 billion in unexpected costs associated with a business that was spun off last year.
Investors also put pressure on conglomerates with operations that are varied, far-flung and hard to fathom. Tyco, a company known for its complex financial statements, lost 20 percent of its value, falling to $33.65 a share. Contributing to investor skittishness was Tyco's disclosure that it had paid $20 million to an outside director and a charity he controls for help in arranging an acquisition last year. 
Even shares of General Electric, one of the nation's bluest chips, fell 4.4 percent, a reflection of investors' fears that the financial statements of companies in multiple lines of business may be too difficult to understand.
Investors are not the only ones bringing greater scrutiny to corporations' accounting practices. The Federal Reserve appears to be taking a closer look at banks' financial positions, too.
The PNC Financial Services Group, Pennsylvania's largest bank, announced yesterday that it would reduce its 2001 net income by $155 million, or 53 cents a share, after Fed officials expressed concerns that the company was improperly accounting for some problem loans and venture capital holdings that it sold last year to three separate entities.
PNC said it had retained only a partial interest in the entities and had included that stake on its books, with the approval of its auditors, Ernst & Young. But the regulators instructed the bank-holding company to consolidate the entire value of the holdings on its balance sheet. Walter Gregg, a vice chairman of the bank, said PNC restated its figures to "avoid confusion going forward and in light of our desire to resolve the issue as quickly as possible."
Shares of Cendant, a company with franchises of residential real estate operations and motels and the owner of the Avis rental car business, also fell sharply. The company has seven partnerships that it has used to move various operations from its books, said Jay Leupp, a stock analyst at Robertson Stephens.
The main purpose of these deals was not to hide debt but to avoid reporting losses, especially accounting charges for acquisitions and other items that do not affect the company's cash flow. Unlike Enron, Cendant disclosed details of each partnership to investors.
Mr. Leupp said the partnerships' debt of $1 billion to $1.5 billion was "not much in comparison to Cendant's $10 billion to $11 billion in total long-term debt." He estimated that shifting operations into the partnerships added 20 to 30 cents to Cendant's earnings in 2001. But investors may be nervous, he said, because once the company moved the units into the partnerships, crucial elements were no longer disclosed. "I wish I could see more of the drivers of their revenue and expenses," Mr. Leupp said.
Phone calls to Cendant were not returned late last night.
Even professional investors who know how to digest financial statements seem to be realizing that they may not truly know what they own.
"It has become much more difficult to make a standard comparison among companies in a world where derivatives and off-balance-sheet transactions are an increasingly significant part of a company's operations," said Jonathan Cohen, portfolio manager at JHC Capital in Greenwich, Conn., and former chief of software and Internet research at Merrill Lynch.
Confidence in the stock market rests on several basic beliefs: that corporate managers will be truthful, that auditors will be able to judge companies' financial positions and that stock analysts and bond rating agencies will be able to analyze how sound or promising companies are. The fall of Enron has shattered all these fundamental beliefs.
As a result, many investors perceive greater risk in almost every publicly traded stock.
"If I own a lot of stocks, now I have to wonder about whether much of the data on which I have based my judgments is accurate or phony," said Stan Jonas, managing director at Fimat USA, a broker-dealer in New York. "If I don't know whether a company is honest or its accountants are honest, I have to act as though it is dishonest. That means I have to discount the price I will pay for it to adjust for that risk."
Mr. Maramarco, the Babson fund manager, said his company had had visits in recent days from two top accounting analysts at Wall Street firms. "Both these people, who clearly know balance sheets and income statements inside out, have thrown up their hands," he said. "They say there are so many ways for companies to obfuscate their financial statements and have their accountants sign off on it that they don't have a chance."

HEADLINE: Near Ground Zero, a Vote to Return to School 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
Parents and teachers at Public School 89, which was evacuated after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, have voted by a wide margin to return to their school on Feb. 28, after five months in temporary quarters.
 The vote, tallied yesterday, apparently ends weeks of bitter conflict over the date of the return: parents questioned whether their children would be harmed, physically or mentally, by returning to the school, which is within a few blocks of ground zero. It will make P.S. 89 the sixth of the seven public schools near the World Trade Center site in Lower Manhattan to return to their regular buildings, bringing the schools a step closer to normality. 
 Sharon Sprague, co-chairwoman of the school's Parents Association, said yesterday that based on the vote, the association had decided to drop its suit to further delay the return. 
"I spoke to the lawyers and I said that, at this moment, I don't have authorization to go forward," she said.
The vote was 191 to 114, or 63 percent to 37 percent, in favor of returning. About 30 teachers cast votes; the others were cast by parents. The school has 240 students. 
Andrew Miltenberg, the pro bono lawyer for the Parents Association, said yesterday that a group of parents still believed, based on independent experts consulted for the lawsuit, that the environmental safety of the neighborhood around P.S. 89 was unknown, especially for children. But he said he had acceded to the wishes of Ms. Sprague.
In the immediate aftermath of the attacks, the school lost about 40 percent of its students, as some families fled the city. The conflict over the return and the decision to take the city to court, parents said, tore the school community apart.
"After 9/11 everyone got scattered like so many sticks thrown in the air," said Robin McKay, a parent at P.S. 89 and a member of the Parents Association's executive board. "So people do want to regain control of their school, they want to grow the community again. Some people went as far as Mexico and they probably won't come back till September -- but would you?"
"It's going to be interesting to all come back together," she added. "I for one, plan to push for a very big party for adults only, just have a huge homecoming."
Chancellor Harold O. Levy also welcomed the decision.
Students at the High School for Leadership and Public Service, just a block south of the trade center site on Trinity Place, are returning to their building today.
But the fate of the last of the seven evacuated schools, the High School of Economics and Finance, remained uncertain yesterday. Their return, scheduled for today, was postponed after teachers found soot in their building, also on Trinity Place, on a walking tour. The board agreed yesterday to a 10-day delay and further cleanup. But some parents were angry that conditions at their host school, Norman Thomas High School in Midtown, were deteriorating. Classes, already cut to 40 minutes from 50 minutes, are now being cut to 30 minutes and the students' shift is being pushed later in the day, to end at 6:30 p.m. instead of 6 p.m.
"These kids are being treated like second-class citizens," said Roy Kessler, a parent.
At P.S. 89, ballots were sent home with students on Friday. But when the ballots were returned on Monday, the Parents Association sealed them and refused to count them because they had a date the same day in Manhattan State Supreme Court seeking to block the reopening. 
In a tense court hearing Monday, the parents and the Board of Education appeared to be at an impasse, with neither side able to negotiate a date beyond Feb. 28, the day the board favored. Judge Michael D. Stallman urged them forward, but declined to set a date himself.
During the hearing, parents clung tightly to a suitcase containing the ballots, while Chad Vignola, the board's lawyer, angrily demanded that the judge force the vote to be counted. Justice Stallman refused, saying that the parents -- not he -- had sent out the ballots and had a right to take possession of whatever was sent back. He advised the parents though, that it would be "utter folly" to destroy them.
On Monday night, the Parents Association sent home a letter saying the ballots would not be counted, because they were irrelevant.
But by yesterday morning, the executive board voted 8 to 2 to count them. "I am not happy with the Feb. 28 return date," Ms. Sprague said. "But you have to take responsibility and get real. This is what we have."

HEADLINE: N.Y.U. and Union Agree On Graduate-Student Pay 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON and STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
New York University and the United Auto Workers announced yesterday that they had reached the first union agreement between a private university and its graduate teaching and research assistants. 
 The four-year agreement, which is subject to a ratification vote scheduled for this afternoon, will raise stipends for many graduate students by nearly 40 percent, provide them with health care benefits and pay them extra if their teaching or research work takes more than 20 hours a week. 
 But the agreement also fulfills N.Y.U.'s main goal, giving it continued control over academic decisions like which courses graduate students will teach and how many students will be in their classes.
The agreement comes as graduate students at Columbia, Brown and several other major universities are also seeking union representation. The N.Y.U. contract is expected to become a model. 
"This was terra incognita," said L. Jay Oliva, N.Y.U.'s president. "No private university had faced this challenge before."
In late 2000, the National Labor Relations Board, then controlled by Democrats, gave graduate teaching assistants at private universities the right to unionize in a case involving N.Y.U. But many union leaders fear that the current labor board, now controlled by Republicans, may soon reverse that policy and from now on deny graduate students in private universities the right to unionize.
At public universities, which are covered by state labor laws, graduate students in many states have been allowed to unionize for years.
The tentative N.Y.U. contract, which covers more than 1,000 graduate assistants, includes a no-strike provision, including a ban on sympathy strikes.
Robert Berne, N.Y.U.'s vice president for academic and health affairs and its lead negotiator, said the stipend increases would be costly but were necessary for N.Y.U. to compete in attracting graduate students.
"We were behind on our stipends and our health care coverage," he said.
Including health care coverage, he said, the contract will raise N.Y.U.'s labor costs for graduate assistants by about 50 percent over four years. Nevertheless, he added: "This is a good contract that serves the university and its graduate assistants well." 
Phil Wheeler, the director of the United Auto Workers for the Northeast, called the contract "a major breakthrough."
"We ended up being able to work out an agreement even though a lot of people said it couldn't be done," he said. "We ended up establishing a decent relationship where we know how to deal with each other in the future."
Some graduate students also expressed delight.
"It's a great agreement," said Julen Esteban-Pretel, a doctoral student in economics. "We've achieved most of the things we want to get. We didn't give up anything. We're going to get substantial raises for everybody. We're going to get health insurance, which is very important."
Until now, stipends for N.Y.U.'s graduate teaching and research assistants generally ranged from $9,000 to $14,000 a year. Under the agreement, stipends will be raised to at least $15,000 this year, retroactive to Sept. 1, with the stipend rising $1,000 a year for the next three years.
The university will also pay half the $1,200 cost of individual health insurance for all graduate assistants this year and the full cost next year. N.Y.U. now pays a third of the cost for about 70 percent of the graduate assistants while the other 30 percent pay for their own coverage. Graduate assistants, who average 20 hours a week over the 30-week academic year, also receive free tuition and fees, valued at $21,000 a year.
The contract covers only a fraction of N.Y.U.'s 18,000 graduate students. Graduate teaching or research assistants in four scientific fields are covered by other contracts.
Kim Williams-Guillen, a doctoral student in anthropology, said she was pleased that if graduate students put in more than 20 hours each week they could be paid more than the stipend.
"Many people found they exceeded that average without any sort of extra compensation," she said.
Now that N.Y.U. has reached agreement with Local 2110 of the autoworkers' union, the union's attention will turn to other private universities where graduate students are seeking to unionize.
At Columbia, where the minimum stipend is $15,000. students have petitioned the labor board to approve a unionization vote. But the university is contesting such a vote, and a labor board decision is expected soon.
"Graduate students who are unsure of the impact a union will have can look at the N.Y.U. contract and see the concrete evidence of the benefits of unionizing," said David Carpio, a third-year doctoral student in biology at Columbia.

HEADLINE: Mink? In a Shirtsleeves Winter?; 
Just as Fur Was Getting Hot, Busy Season Turned Balmy

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
In a little more than a year, Bobbi Rudd, the owner of a real estate company in Manhattan, has bought herself four fur coats.
 Her collection includes a lightweight unlined olive-green coat made of sheared woven rabbit, with a matching scarf; a wine-colored collarless sheared mink coat; and a reversible coat that is sheared black mink on one side and steel-gray leather on the other. 
 "I love furs that don't look like fur," said Mrs. Rudd, of the Upper West Side, as she shopped for a sheared mink lining for her daughter-in-law's microfiber raincoat at Goldin Feldman, a third-generation furrier on 30th Street, in the heart of what is left of Manhattan's fur district.
Mink is still the preferred choice of most women who buy fur, but the wide variety of styles and techniques -- shearing, plucking, knitting and even embroidery -- have helped to reinvigorate the fur industry after many lean years. 
Until only recently, fur seemed to be making a strong comeback. The animal rights movement had been steadily losing steam in this country (although not in Europe), the economy was good and designers who had been afraid for political reasons to work with fur were using it again. In 2000, fur sales nationwide reached $1.69 billion, an increase of 21 percent from 1999.
But instead of repeating that success, many furriers are having a tough time this winter. The faltering stock market and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are partly to blame, but industry experts cite an even more critical factor: the unusually balmy weather.
Temperatures have been so warm this winter -- a record was set yesterday -- that a couple of hundred fur coats are still hanging in the storage room at Ritz Furs, a resale shop on 57th Street, because their owners have apparently felt no urgency to retrieve them.
No official sales figures are available, but William Brenner, a fur dealer since 1969, estimated that business in the city's fur district was off by as much as 30 percent. "If it starts getting cold early in the season," Mr. Brenner said, "women go out and buy -- period. If it's warm, they say, 'Oh, I can wait.' It's a mind-set."
In a business driven more by psychological needs than practical considerations, impulse plays a large role. "Fur is very much of an emotional buy," said Steve Gold, the North American marketing director for Saga Furs of Scandinavia, an organization that promotes the use of fur. "You have to wait for that right moment."
Retailers say the weather may have deterred customers from buying coats, but have not slowed sales of scarves, hats, bags and other fur accessories. "They're still very hot," said Keith Tauber, the manager of Ritz Furs, which also sells novelty items like mink cases for cellphones. Fur trim -- fox for a coat collar, for example -- is also doing well this season, industry experts say.
Situated since the 1920's at the northern end of Chelsea, from 26th Street to 31st Street, between Sixth and Eighth Avenues, the fur district used to be a world unto itself, with hangouts like Hershey's Dairy, and its famously bossy waiters, and Traders, where the specialty was London broil on twin seeded rolls. Those restaurants are long gone, as is the Fur Center Synagogue and the two auction houses.
These days, furriers, like garment manufacturers, are competing for space with lawyers and dot-com companies. Rising real estate prices have forced many furriers to team up and split the rent. Robert Englander, who oversees production at Miller & Berkowitz, a 52-year-old family business, estimated that rents had tripled over the last few years. With the economic downturn, annual rents are beginning to drop slightly -- from $27 a square foot to $25 -- but not enough to make a difference.
Many showrooms now list several names on the door. The factory where Miller & Berkowitz produces chinchilla coats that Neiman Marcus sells for $75,000 is shared with four other furriers, and the company is now leasing most of its storage space in New Jersey. 
Today, only one building in the fur district, at 150 West 30th Street, is occupied exclusively by furriers. But that distinction may soon disappear because two floors are currently on the market.
One of the empty floors used to be leased by Pologeorgis Furs, a family business established in the 1960's, when Greek furriers began playing a prominent role in the industry. As his lease was about to expire and his rent was about to double, Nick Pologeorgis, the company president -- and, at 39, said to be one of the youngsters in an aging industry -- took the bold step of buying a loft on 29th Street.
In 2000, Mr. Pologeorgis said, he had his best year. Last year started off well, but then sales weakened. Now he is eagerly waiting for sales figures from the department stores that account for 90 percent of his business.
The fur industry underwent significant change in the 1970's, when merchants like Fred the Furrier and Antonovich began marketing fur as a mass-market product. Some furriers say this broadened the customer base, but others contend that it cheapened fur's image, driving some customers away. "If my housekeeper is wearing a mink coat, why would I want to?" said Anne Dee Goldin, the owner of Goldin Feldman. "The furriers did this to themselves."
By the late 1980's, most of the manufacturing had moved abroad, primarily to Asia, to take advantage of the cheaper labor. But fur became popular again, Ms. Goldin said, when young designers like Narciso Rodriguez began working with it.
As of last year, the city had only 81 fur companies employing 450 workers, according to the State Department of Labor, down from about 450 companies and 2,254 workers in 1987. (Fur New York, a trade group, estimates that there are actually 150 to 200 remaining companies, but says some are independent contractors with no employees.)
Some furriers moved to Long Island City, but most companies simply disappeared, often because no one was left to run the business. 
Despite this year's setbacks, Mr. Gold said that many furriers earn a good living catering to the upper end of the market, where a mink coat made by a painstaking process that has changed very little over the years can cost as much as $20,000 and a sable coat $25,000 or much more. Most sell both wholesale and retail, often charging customers as much as 40 percent less than they would pay in a department store. (Today, however, it is also possible to negotiate the price of a fur at a department store, said Keith Kaplan, a spokesman for the Fur Information Council of America, a trade group.)
These days, a customer can buy a sheared mink coat that is made to look like a corduroy trench coat, a sable coat that reverses to suede or a shearling jacket that weighs little more than a sweater.
These designs are aimed at customers like Tamar Harraway, 35, of Queens, who already owns a full-length mink coat and a swing jacket made of sheared rabbit. "I'm looking for an everyday coat," said Ms. Harraway, a computer engineer, as she tried on a $4,500 whiskey-colored mink coat, designed by Karl Lagerfeld, and a green sheared muskrat jacket at Ritz Furs.
And why does she like fur? "It's just this feeling you get," she said, "It's classy and you can dress it up with a hat. Fur is fun, very fun."
Like many young women today, Gloria, a 34-year-old single nurse from the Bronx, was not waiting for a man to buy her a fur coat. Gloria, who did not want her last name published, chose a traditional, full-length mink. Such coats account for at least 80 percent of fur sales, according to Mr. Kaplan.
Gloria, who paid $1,500 for a refurbished coat, said she felt it was something she deserved. "There comes a time in every woman's life," she said, "when she needs pearls, diamonds and a beautiful mink coat."

HEADLINE: For City, Good Buzz May Be Best Payoff Of Economic Forum 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Money pumped into New York's economy by bigwigs on a spree at the schmoozefest called the World Economic Forum: $13 million or $19.4 million, depending on how you figure it.
 Cost of protecting said bigwigs from protesters bent on disrupting the aforementioned schmoozefest, a k a Davos on the Hudson: more than $11 million. 
 Value of international television coverage of the forum (even if such coverage consists mainly of men in rimless spectacles discussing impenetrable topics in incomprehensible accents): priceless.
That, at least, is the theory over at NYC & Company, the tourism-boosting outfit that is helping to bring the forum to New York City, starting Thursday. "Broadcasting overseas that New York City is open for business is priceless," said Cristyne L. Nicholas, president of the quasi-governmental agency, which is eager to bring free-spending foreign tourists back to the city. 
All of the figures cited above are so fuzzy that they should come with footnotes. But if security costs are higher than they have been at past events, and if spending by visitors is lower, it is possible that the costs and benefits will balance each other out. Which means, in effect, that money would move out of the hands of taxpayers through the forum and into the till of the Waldorf-Astoria, the main site of the event.
The figures are also projections, which often do not pan out, as Seattle found out when it played host to the World Trade Organization in 1999. Seattle expected to spend $6 million on security while local businesses raked in $11 million; instead, the city spent $9 million -- 50 percent more than expected -- and local businesses say they lost $17 million after violent protesters destroyed property downtown and the police declared a state of emergency.
Still, even New York City's strictest budget watchdogs think the city will benefit from the attention generated by the forum and similar events. "This one may or may not be a loss leader," said Doug Turetsky, communications director for the Independent Budget Office. "But it helps market and expand New York's image as a host of world and national and international forums."
A lot will depend on how calm the protesters and the police remain (and how coddled the dignitaries feel). 
"If it goes well, it's a coming-out party for the City of New York, and it's worth a lot of money," said John Tepper Marlin, chief economist for the city comptroller's office. He says the overall value of the event could reach $250 million (which may sound like a lot, but it's far less than the economic value of the United States Open tennis championship in Queens). "If it goes badly, it's a big negative." 
The last time the city was the site of a similar gathering of international pooh-bahs and corporate potentates was in 1999, at the millennium summit meeting of the United Nations.
But that wingding attracted fewer than 200 V.V.V.I.P.'s. The forum this week will include more than 1,000 business leaders paying $25,000 a head, 200 "academic experts," 300 "media leaders" and "nearly 300 public figures" (it's unclear which category includes the sculptor and art therapist from France, or, for that matter, a certain former mayor). And the United Nations summit meeting did not attract thousands of young people planning to dress up as giant squid and avenge the ills of the world by protesting at the Gap.
Even so, police overtime during that three-day event cost $11 million, according to the Independent Budget Office. (The last Subway Series and Yankees victory parade cost $4.6 million.)
The Police Department has not said how much it expects to spend on overtime; asked if anyone had talked about the police costs, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said no. Asked at a news conference on Monday how much New York taxpayers would pony up for security, the forum's organizers ignored the question, but did say that their meeting's direct economic benefit would be $12 million to $18 million.
They attributed that figure to NYC & Company, which itself is using $13 million or $19.4 million. The agency came up with those numbers by calculating the percentage spent on food, shopping, transportation and lodging by a typical visitor. 
It then plugged in a secret figure for how much the forum's guests will spend on lodging (secret but big -- room rates start at $365 a night for the shindig). Multiply that by 3,000 guests and voila: $13 million.
The total jumps to $19.4 million if you include a multiplier (roughly 1.5) that is standard in the tourism business and tries to estimate the ripple effects of tourist spending. For purposes of comparison, the Belmont Stakes usually bring in about $6.3 million to the city's economy. And in 1999, the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade generated $23.3 million, according to the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
NYC & Company's projections are very conservative, Ms. Nicholas said, pointing out that they do not include the huge sums being spent on soirees at restaurants like the Four Seasons, or even the amount that the protesters will be shelling out at vegetarian restaurants across the five boroughs. And the attendees at the forum tend to be big spenders, whose idea of a nice New York souvenir is a Tiffany crystal apple, not a thermometer shaped like the Empire State Building.
The big question, of course, is whether the forum attendees will actually get out and spend in New York's stores and restaurants, or whether they will be locked inside the Waldorf by protests (or by discussion topics like "Attracting Capital Inflows in a Risk-Averse Environment").
Ms. Nicholas said her agency had made special efforts to ensure that the participants "in fact will not be locked inside the Waldorf." Bus trips are planned to museums as far away as Queens, and special shopping expeditions will be made to Saks Fifth Avenue before and after the usual hours.
And to please the truly intrepid forum attendee, Ms. Nicholas has a special gift: MetroCards. So keep your eyes open on the bus.

HEADLINE: Davos on the Hudson 

 BODY:
Many corporate gatherings have themes, but the World Economic Forum may be the only one that has a human ideal. The Davos Man, named for the Swiss town where the conference has been held for the past 32 years, is a model of globe-trotting, high-tech, New Economy savvy. And for the next five days some 3,000 Davos Men, and a sprinkling of Davos Women, will descend on the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City from around the world, Blackberry personal messaging devices in hand and silk ties flapping in the wind. 
 The world's pre-eminent powerfest, Davos -- as everyone still calls it -- is being held in Manhattan to express solidarity with post-Sept. 11 New York. This year's theme is "leadership in fragile times," and many of the conference's panels and workshops have been tailored to the economic, political and spiritual fallout of last year's tragic events. If history is any guide, however, these high-minded tutorials will be hard pressed to compete with the week's tightly packed schedule of cocktail parties and networking luncheons, many put on by the 1,000 major corporations underwriting the forum. 
 Globalization is by nature a diffuse target, which is why this gathering -- like World Trade Organization and Group of 8 meetings in recent years in Seattle and Genoa -- will be a tempting target for critics of the new world order. Anarchists, Socialists, labor unionists, opponents of industrial pollution, supporters of third-world debt relief and other members of the anti-globalism movement are expected to show up in force. New York City's Police Department has already declared a zero-tolerance policy for lawbreaking during the conference, which it insists will extend to littering, jaywalking and violations of an obscure and constitutionally dubious state law against three or more people appearing in public in masks.
The forum's organizers say they hope the move away from Davos, a winter playland for the rich, nestled in the Alps, will establish a more sober tone for this year's meeting. New York has been in a contemplative mood in recent months, one that all the event's participants could emulate, starting with the invited guests. Davos has traditionally been far more ready to celebrate globalism than to reflect on the harm that can result as corporations become increasingly untethered to any specific place. This year the forum's organizers have invited a number of human rights activists, union officials and advocates for the world's poor to participate in panels and workshops. Further moves in this direction could transform Davos into an enlightening experience for the participants, and a more valuable forum for addressing world problems.
Anti-globalism protesters would also do well to adopt a more solemn tone, consistent with recent events. After the destruction of the World Trade Center, the sort of violent clashes that broke out in Seattle and Genoa no longer generate the same anti-authority frisson. The anti-globalism message will be best received, certainly by violence-weary New Yorkers, if it is delivered not by physical confrontation and broken store windows but by appeals to reason and conscience.
Law enforcement should also act with restraint. At a time when Americans are reflecting on the nation's most cherished values, Davos Men and Women should be able to convene in New York to plan their new world, while ordinary men and women freely and peacefully gather to protest the meeting.

HEADLINE: Japan's Foreign Minister Is Fired After Months of Feuding 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 30 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi fired his foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, on Tuesday, ending a tumultuous nine-month alliance in which two of Japan's most popular politicians tried to balance their reformist tactics in the same government.
 "I asked them if they were firing me, and the prime minister himself said yes," Ms. Tanaka said minutes after leaving a political meeting at Mr. Koizumi's residence. "The prime minister himself told me he was replacing me." 
 As the first woman to be Japan's foreign minister, Ms. Tanaka, 57, had won legions of followers by criticizing Japan's conservative old guard. But her constant feuding with bureaucrats made her a liability for Mr. Koizumi, who started the new year facing a worsening economic situation and a number of diplomatic challenges.
Her firing was seen by political analysts and voters alike as a sign that Mr. Koizumi was giving in to the conservative old guard in an effort to stabilize his weakening government. But Ms. Tanaka's departure could actually undermine Mr. Koizumi, alienating her supporters and leaving the prime minister and the ailing economy in the spotlight. 
In early trading today, the bellwether Nikkei average of the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell below 10,000 for the first time since Nov. 13. Market analysts attributed the drop in part to political uncertainty surrounding the Koizumi government.
A year ago, Ms. Tanaka was Japan's most popular politician, based on public opinion polls. But by the time a conference was held here last week on Afghan aid, she had been reduced to a figurehead.
This morning, Japanese newspapers speculated that Mr. Koizumi would try to tap another woman as foreign minister, Sadako Ogata, who won high praise as the co-chairwoman of the aid conference. Ms. Ogata, a Ford Foundation fellow who spends much of her time in New York, served for 10 years as the United Nations high commissioner for refugees.
After the roller coaster of Ms. Tanaka's tenure -- in which she was involved in controversies over government leaks, fired secretaries and a missed imperial garden party -- many Japanese say a professional is needed to run foreign policy.
During her time in office, Ms. Tanaka had complained that bureaucrats had cut her out of the flow of information, had not told her about meetings and had isolated her in an office that contained no international newspapers, foreign language dictionaries or even a map of the world. 
Mr. Koizumi's decision to change foreign ministers comes just as a number of world leaders are arriving to do business with Japan. On Friday, Igor Ivanov, Russia's foreign minister, is to arrive here in an effort to break a half-century old logjam over four islands occupied by Russia and claimed by Japan. Ms. Tanaka had publicly criticized Mr. Koizumi's approach to the issue, which has prevented Japan from signing a peace treaty with Russia, sealing the end of World War II.
On Feb. 17, President Bush is to come here for a two-day visit. Much of the visit is expected to revolve around American concern over Japan's worsening economy. On Tuesday, the government reported that unemployment rose to 5.6 percent in December after a 7.9 percent fall in industrial production last year.
In May and June, the World Cup soccer championship is take place in Japan and South Korea, two countries that often have complicated relations because of Japan's occupation of the Korean peninsula in the first half of the 20th century. Relations with China, Japan's new economic rival, will also be in the spotlight this year as a series of events are to mark 30 years since the nations reestablished diplomatic ties.
It was Ms. Tanaka's father, Kakuei Tanaka, who renewed ties with China in 1972 when he was prime minister. 
Also fired on Tuesday night was Vice Foreign Minister Yoshiji Nogami, the ministry's top civil servant.
The two had contradicted each other in the national Parliament, the Diet, in recent days over the participation of two nongovernmental Japanese organizations in the conference on Afghan aid. The clash, with accusations of lying, pushed Ms. Tanaka to the point of tears in a television interview on Friday.
The incident further escalated when Prime Minister Koizumi responded: "Tears are women's greatest weapons. When women cry, men cannot compete with them."
In response, 18 female opposition members of the Diet went to the premier's residence on Tuesday to show solidarity with Ms. Tanaka, a member since 1993. They said in a statement, "The prime minister has biased views on women's expressions, anger and grief."
In a move that may dent his popularity -- a 72 percent approval rating in a poll released last weekend -- Mr. Koizumi said that he was too busy to receive the women because he was working on a supplemental budget.
An hour after the lower house passed the $19 billion budget additions, Mr. Koizumi summoned Ms. Tanaka to his residence and fired her and Mr. Nogami.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Makiko Tanaka, shown last week in Tokyo, was fired yesterday from her post as Japan's foreign minister. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Journal; 
It's Good Talk, but Bad Language

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 25 

 BODY:
Juan Manuel Garcia-Passalacqua is a political analyst, a newspaper columnist and a professor. He graduated from Harvard Law School, has written more than a dozen books on politics and was an adviser on Latin America and the Caribbean in the Carter White House.
 But every morning this 65-year-old grandfather of six turns into a no-holds-barred radio talk show host so foul-mouthed, so crude, that objection comes even from his wife of four decades, Ivonne Acosta, who says she has not listened to the show for over a year. 
 "I don't listen to it so we don't fight," said Ms. Acosta, herself a historian and university professor. "I use cuss words in private, but it offends me when I hear them on the radio. The mocking and the insults, I don't go along with that." 
While many disapprove and tune out, many more keep listening, even if that means blushing. After three years on the air throughout Puerto Rico, Mr. Garcia-Passalacqua's show, "Analyzing With Juanma," on the Noti-Uno radio network, beats all AM competitors in its time slot, 9 to 10 a.m. weekdays. He divides the show between his commentary on the day's headlines and taking calls from listeners, many of whom seem torn: wanting to hear the message of so well informed a source, yet wanting to kill the messenger for the way he delivers it.
"I want to ask you, as the mother of a 6-year-old, to change your vocabulary," a woman told him recently in one of the many calls he gets from people taking him to task for his expletives and vulgar colloquialisms. "You're an intelligent man. You know you don't have to go that far."
Despite some listeners' threats to complain to the government, Mr. Garcia-Passalacqua says he has yet to hear a word from the F.C.C.
His radio persona -- which frequently takes aim at local corruption and the island's commonwealth status, among other targets -- evolved not as a ratings gimmick, he says, but out of frustration. For decades he advocated sovereignty for Puerto Rico (though with ties to the United States, including a right to dual citizenship) in books and the language of an educated elite, and "I achieved nothing." Now, he says, he is using the vernacular of the masses to reach those on the margins of Puerto Rico's economic and political life, "a population that votes blindly."
"I want the average citizen to join in the search for a solution to Puerto Rico's colonial situation," he said. "I have not convinced them, but I have grabbed them." 
Some defend Mr. Garcia-Passalacqua's regular use of obscenities, agreeing with him that the end justifies what he sees as effective means. Others say a creeping intrusion of foul language, not only on radio but occasionally on television and in newspapers as well, reflects a general deterioration of standards.
"It's a product of the economic difficulties in Puerto Rico," said Jaime L. Rodriguez-Cancel, academic dean at the Center for Advanced Studies of Puerto Rico and the Caribbean, an independent graduate school where Mr. Garcia-Passalacqua teaches and is widely supported. "Unemployment grows, and people find only minimum-wage jobs. The problems of drugs, money laundering, corruption, the underground economy, all this affects social behavior."
Whatever the cause, and whatever his good intentions, many Puerto Ricans remain stunned that his kind of on-air language comes from someone with the stature of Mr. Garcia-Passalacqua.
At the Center for Advanced Studies, where he is teaching a doctoral course this semester on United States military policy in 20th-century Puerto Rico, students describe him as a rigorous, well-organized professor with a vast knowledge of his subject and personal insights from his political experiences, including appointments as legal counsel and chief aide to two Puerto Rican governors in the 1960's. 
Yet on his show he has called the governor of Puerto Rico, Sila M. Calderon, "the old woman" and much worse, and last October accused her of adultery with a cabinet member. (The governor, who is in the midst of divorce proceedings, refused to comment on the remarks other than to call them "disrespectful," and even her estranged husband came to her defense.)
All this notwithstanding, Mr. Garcia-Passalacqua is evidently not altogether comfortable with his dual role. He has tried to make a distinction between Juanma, the irascible political analyst, and Professor Garcia-Passalacqua, the teacher who pops up on the show once a week to lecture in what he calls "la escuelita," the little school.
"It's an ethical sacrifice," he said of his radio alter ego. "I would have liked to end my career as the doctoral professor who taught at Yale. It seems absurd, but my country is asking me for something else."

HEADLINE: Neighbors of Economic Forum Prepare for the Worst 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
The Gap is dusting off its policy manual for store managers, with guidance for handling mayhem at the door. Starbucks is working with the police so cappuccinos can be dispensed and consumed in safety. Citicorp has called in Labrador retrievers.
 Fearful of being the targets of vandalism, large corporations near the site of the World Economic Forum are taking those and other defensive steps as the conference draws near -- it starts tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria at 301 Park Avenue, in Midtown Manhattan. 
 The New York Police Department and other law enforcement agencies are preparing to close off streets and deploy thousands of officers for the meeting, and nearby businesses are busy with their own security and safety plans, although few would talk about them in specific terms.
Starbucks, which suffered vandalism at previous economic conferences, has eight stores near the Waldorf-Astoria and a total of 122 in Manhattan. The Gap, a past target of peaceful protests, is bracing for a demonstration tomorrow at a store at 54th Street and Fifth Avenue.
Citicorp, at 399 Park Avenue and 53rd Street on the route of a Saturday march planned by demonstrators, has called in dogs that have been trained to sniff for explosives, said Ron Bellistri, the chief executive of Copstat Security Inc., which provides security for the bank.
Holding the economic conference in New York has raised myriad security concerns for a city that, since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, has found ways to manage public order during big events like the World Series and United Nations meetings.
The economic conference will present problems that are, in some ways, more manageable than past threats, like the possibility of terrorism at the New Year's celebration for the millennium. "In the millennium, we did not have a clearly identifiable group," Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said recently. "It was a threat, but the threat was not easily defined; it was general. Here, we know that there are activists that come to these things who are out to cause a problem, so it is more specific things in that sense."
The protesters, mainly from labor, environmental and student movements critical of the growing global power of multinational corporations, are promising only peaceful demonstrations. Anarchists say that some radical elements, though, have said they do not consider property destruction -- like breaking store windows without injuring people -- to be violence.
Norman Siegel, a civil rights lawyer and the director of the Freedom, Legal Defense and Education Project who plans to be on the streets in the coming days as a legal observer, said property destruction must be viewed as breaking the law.
He added, "Some of the corporate executives might want to sit down and listen to some of the peaceful protesters' grievances to begin a dialogue."
Though no plywood boards could be seen going up in street level windows yesterday, the view from the front steps of the Waldorf-Astoria, between 49th and 50th Streets, was a corporate panorama: banks and other financial institutions to the north and, to the south, more brokerages and banks, a Starbucks store, the logo of the MetLife building and the rear of Grand Central Terminal, with its high-end shops.
As for security at the Waldorf-Astoria itself, Shelley Clark, a spokeswoman, would not discuss it other than to say that "clearly there is concern."
When the conferees seek to navigate the streets outside the Waldorf-Astoria, at least 100 of them will be passengers in new Audi automobiles driven by armed retired and active law enforcement officers. When they get to their cocktail parties or other soirees, armed guards will be mingling among them, said John F. Timoney -- a former deputy New York police commissioner and now chief executive of Beau Dietl & Associates, which will be handling some security during the conference. 
Not all the preparations anticipate violence. At St. Bartholomew's Church, the Rev. William M. Tully, the rector, said he planned to keep the church's doors open to provide a refuge for any who may need it, be they anarchists or Fifth Avenue power shoppers. "Our building manager has been meeting with the police for weeks, and we are trying to learn everything we can," Father Tully said. "Part of our calling is to be a church that is open and accessible to everyone."

(Edward Keating/The New York Times) Map of New York City higlighting area of Economic Forum: A variety of outlets of capitalism in the blocks near the conference hotel.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Tyson Has Only Himself to Blame for Turndown

BYLINE:  By DAVE ANDERSON 

 BODY:
INSTEAD of his usual hip-hop clothes, Mike Tyson was wearing his most sincere suit -- gray with a white shirt and a gray tie.
 "I'm no Mother Teresa," he told the five members of the Nevada State Athletic Commission, "but I'm not Charles Manson either." 
 But they knew he was Mike Tyson, and that was enough. In a 4-to-1 vote, the commission denied the license that would have allowed the 35-year-old former champion to challenge Lennox Lewis for two-thirds of the world heavyweight title in a bout that had been planned for April 6 at the MGM Grand hotel-casino in Las Vegas. 
Tyson has only himself to blame -- not merely for last week's melee with Lewis at a news conference, but also for so many other incidents, notably biting Evander Holyfield's ears and touching off the MGM Grand casino riot that followed that 1997 bout; his 1992 rape conviction, and the possibility of a new rape charge in Las Vegas.
"The patterns," the commissioner Amy Ayoub said at one point, "of uncontrolled violent behavior."
Tyson pleaded that the planned April 6 bout would be the "most important moment of his life" in boxing. But the commission, often accused of being a conduit for Nevada's gambling industry, decided yesterday that Tyson was more trouble than the multimillions of dollars he would have been worth to the MGM Grand and the Las Vegas economy.
In rejecting Tyson during the nation's economic recession when Las Vegas needs all the millions it can get, the commission showed something seldom seen in boxing: integrity.
Now the search begins for another site. And be assured that this Lewis-Tyson fight will resurface at another site. If not in another state, then elsewhere in the world.
With so many millions involved, if a state commission can't justify licensing Tyson, the promoters (Main Events and Mike Tyson Enterprises) and their pay-per-view partners (HBO and Showtime) will take the fight to any European, Asian or African country that will sanction it and can afford it.
Without a Las Vegas site, the guarantees elsewhere probably won't match the $17.5 million that Lewis and Tyson each would have received if the fight had remained at the MGM Grand.
In recent years, virtually all the big fights, especially those for the heavyweight title, have been held in Las Vegas because the hotel-casinos there can afford it. They invite their high rollers, usually those with at least a $50,000 credit line, to arrive for the weekend with complimentary rooms and ringside tickets. The hotel counts on the probability of recouping its investment in the fight from the high rollers' losses in the casino.
But in the perverse way that often adds to the appeal of boxing, the controversy over Tyson's license in Nevada will probably add to the worldwide attraction of a Lewis-Tyson bout.
Boxing has no borders. Muhammad Ali, you may remember, couldn't get a license anywhere in the United States after losing to Larry Holmes in 1980, but the Bahamas welcomed him.
In a ring surrounded by wooden grandstands on a baseball field near Nassau in the Bahamas, Ali was dominated by Trevor Berbick in a 10-round decision in 1981, the sad finale to a sparkling 21-year career that began shortly after he won an Olympic gold medal in Rome.
When the bell does ring somewhere for the Lewis-Tyson bout, Lewis, the two-thirds champion as the holder of the World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation belts, will be the favorite.
If Lewis is aggressive early, he could register a quick knockout because Tyson will be in range of Lewis's right hand. But even if Lewis controls the pace, Tyson's power gives him a puncher's chance.
Against Francois Botha, a valid heavyweight contender, three years ago, Tyson lost the first four rounds. In the fifth, his left hook knocked out Botha.
Since then, Tyson has fought only five times -- knockouts of Julius Francis in England, Lou Savarese in Scotland and Brian Nielsen in Denmark as well as no-contests with Orlin Norris in Las Vegas and Andrew Golota in Auburn Hills, Mich. In his seven-round knockout of Nielsen last Oct. 13, Tyson weighed 239 pounds, the heaviest of his 49-3 career, with 43 knockouts.
Mike Tyson is now more of a carnival act than a boxer, but wherever this fight with Lennox Lewis resurfaces, the curious won't be able to resist watching pay-per-view to see if the carnival act has one punch left.

HEADLINE: 17 Are Charged in Theft of Sept. 11 Funds 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT F. WORTH 

 BODY:
Twelve employees of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and five others were charged yesterday with filing false claims and stealing money intended for victims of the Sept. 11 attack from a government agency and charities, the authorities said.
 All but one of the Port Authority employees were in the World Trade Center at the time of the attack, but all escaped safely and suffered no financial hardship as a result, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said at a news conference yesterday. 
 The employees, who have all resigned or been suspended since the investigation began, got $19,581 from the American Red Cross and Safe Horizon after filing claims stating that they had become unemployed because of the attack, he said. 
The fraud was discovered after a Port Authority union representative blew the whistle on several employees, prompting the agency to begin an investigation, said Robert E. Van Etten, the inspector general of the Port Authority. Four of the 12 employees charged yesterday then came forward voluntarily, he added.
Four other people were charged separately yesterday with stealing $20,697 from the Federal Emergency Management Agency by falsely claiming their apartments were damaged during the attacks. Three of them are related, and the fourth is a family friend, Mr. Morgenthau said. Another person who works for a Long Island real estate leasing company that does not have offices in the trade center was charged with filing a forged letter from her employer to apply for benefits from the state workers' compensation fund and Safe Horizon.
Mr. Van Etten said the agency was reviewing the records of its 7,500 employees to check for possible fraud. The district attorney's office is also investigating about 50 other people -- most of them not Port Authority employees -- who may also have filed false claims, Mr. Morgenthau said.
Yesterday's arrests bring the number of Port Authority employees charged with making false claims in connection with the attack to 24. In November, 12 cafeteria workers employed by the Port Authority were arrested on charges that they stole more than $14,000 in disaster relief money from the American Red Cross by falsely claiming that they had lost their jobs because of the attack. Three of those charged yesterday were also cafeteria workers.
"We take these charges seriously and may ask for jail sentences," Mr. Morgenthau said. The defendants are accused of falsifying business records and other felonies that are punishable by up to seven years in prison.
Cheryl M. Ivery and Beverly Jones, two Port Authority accounting clerks who were charged yesterday, said after their arraignments that they had been injured during the attack and had not made false claims.
"The Red Cross said I was eligible," Ms. Jones said. She said she had injured her leg in the attack, and had resigned from her job in early October, shortly after applying for assistance. She got $1,500 from the Red Cross, she said.
