HEADLINE: Panel Approves Huge Rail Plan to Move Coal 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 

 BODY:
Federal regulators today approved the largest railroad construction project in modern history, a 900-mile $1.4 billion line to help move Wyoming coal to power plants in the East and Midwest.
 The Surface Transportation Board cited economic and transportation benefits in endorsing a proposal by the Dakota, Minnesota and Eastern Railroad Corporation. The board imposed nearly 150 requirements to address concerns over environmental damage and noise. 
 The plan calls for 280 miles of new track from coal beds in the Powder River Basin in northeastern Wyoming and through the Black Hills in South Dakota, as well as rebuilding 600 miles from southwestern South Dakota across southern Minnesota to the Mississippi River.
"The last time a project of this size was undertaken as a single rail-construction project in the United States, Abraham Lincoln was the president," said Kevin V. Schieffer, president of the railroad.
Significant hurdles remain before construction can begin. The railroad has to obtain building permits from the Army Corps of Engineers and the United States Forest Service. It hopes to complete the line by 2007.
Critics said they would continue to oppose the project, which would take the railroad through the Buffalo Gap National Grassland in South Dakota and the Thunder Basin National Grassland in Wyoming.
"We're fully prepared to file suit," said Nancy Darnell, a rancher in Newcastle, Wyo., who said the rumbling trains would spoil the tranquillity of her land.
The Surface Transportation Board, an arm of the Transportation Department, acknowledged that the project might cause "potentially significant" environmental problems. It said the economic benefits outweighed that possibility. But the board added conditions aimed at limiting the disruption for Indian tribes and other residents, as well as wildlife and natural areas, along the route.
The railroad estimates that demand for Powder River Basin coal will grow from 300 million tons in 1996 to more than 500 million tons by 2010. The company also says its project will produce 6,000 construction jobs over two years, 2,000 permanent jobs related to the railroad, more coal-mining jobs and other economic benefits.
Mr. Schieffer said that agriculture would also benefit from the new rail and that new manufacturers would emerge along the line.
"This is not a coal project," Mr. Schieffer said. "It is a railroad infrastructure project."
When the new line opens, the company envisions moving dozens of trains a day, each with 115 to 135 cars running at up to 45 miles an hour. Three trains a day now haul an average of 57 cars each at 17 miles an hour. 
It is the length, frequency and speed of the proposed schedule that drew complaints from cities like Pierre, S.D., and Rochester, Minn. The president of a neighborhood association in Rochester, Michael LaPlante, predicted that the line would be disastrous for residents.
"The fallout," Mr. LaPlante said, "will almost certainly contribute to the demise of a neighborhood."

HEADLINE: Complex Deal Is First Step To Create New National Park 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 

 BODY:
The Nature Conservancy announced the signing today of a $31 million purchase agreement for a 151-square-mile ranch in Colorado, a complex deal that is the first step toward creating a new national park with the adjacent Great Sand Dunes National Monument and Preserve, in the San Luis Valley.
 The ranch and the national monument are to become the nation's 58th national park in 2005 and will include 70 species of plants and animals that are found nowhere else in the world. The area includes 750-foot-high sand dunes, the tallest in North America, and two peaks, Kit Carson Peak and Challenger Point, that are higher than 14,000 feet. All will become accessible to the public when the deal is completed. 
 The purchase agreement still hinges on the resolution of legal action between the current owner of the property, the Cabeza de Vaca Land and Cattle Company, LLC, and two of its minor investors over water and a right of way claim. Yale University, which is not involved in the legal action, was revealed last week to be a principal investor in the company, prompting Yale's president, Richard C. Levin, to promise that the university would contribute its part of the profits of the sale to the Nature Conservancy.
The ranch, called Baca Ranch, dates from an 1824 Mexican land grant and spreads over 97,000 acres. The conservancy plans to buy it and then sell it to the federal government for inclusion in the national park. Congress has already appropriated $10 million toward the purchase price and is expected to appropriate $17 million more. The deal was proposed in the Clinton administration by Colorado lawmakers, and the Bush administration supports it.
"This is public-private partnership at its best," Gale Norton, the secretary of the interior, said in a statement. "This is a great example of a local grassroots involvement to develop a national park with solid community support."
The amount that Yale is to donate to the sale has yet to be determined, but university officials have said it would be about $4 million. Yale owned half of Vaca Partners, which joined the Cabeza de Vaca company to buy the ranch in 1995 for $15 million. The partnership then tried to sell the water rights, which are potentially highly lucrative, but local residents opposed the sale.
Yale's involvement was revealed last week by a group of union members at Yale who have been at odds with the university and saw its involvement with the water-rights speculation as ethically questionable because the residents opposed such a transaction.
The aquifer under the Baca Ranch helps keep the dunes in place and is vital to the local farm and ranch economies. The Nature Conservancy is acquiring the rights to it.
"The protection of the Baca Ranch essentially completes the conservation of what biologists call a functional area, meaning that all the pieces necessary to sustain the plants and animals native to this area will be protected," said Michael Horak, a spokesman for the conservancy.
The last new national park added to the system was Black Canyon of the Gunnison, also in Colorado, in 1999. The 57 national parks have 385 sub-units, which include presidential birthplaces and Civil War battlefields.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Nature Conservancy announced yesterday that it had signed a purchase agreement for the 151-square-mile Baca Ranch in Colorado. The acquisition is expected to result in a new national park, the nation's 58th. (J. D. Marston/The Nature Conservancy)

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: THE PLAYERS; 
Appearing in the Role of Evil: The Other Side

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
The first act of a major theatrical production opens today in the streets of New York, as thousands gather inside the Waldorf-Astoria for an exclusive event called the World Economic Forum, and thousands more muster outside for protest. Advanced billing for the spectacle, which has a limited engagement of five days, promises stimulating and perhaps even violent confrontation between good and evil.
 What distinguishes this drama is that no one will accept the role of evil antagonist; all of the actors claim to represent goodness, light and the best that the city has to offer. These players also know that they are performing on a world stage with a New York backdrop, where any aggressive act caught on videotape -- smashing a Starbucks window, jostling a doe-eyed protester -- will color their reputation for years to come. 
 Then there is the delicate matter of respecting a weary and impatient audience: city residents for whom Sept. 11 seems like yesterday, for whom the trauma of the World Trade Center disaster is fresh. Every action and reaction, it seems, will be interpreted through the prism of ground zero -- every raised placard, every raised truncheon, every raised cocktail. 
And so the many sides have gone to great lengths to explain why they are doing what they are doing, and why the motivations of others are not in the best interests of either the city or humankind. The forum's organizers say they are bringing together the world's best minds to solve the world's worst problems. The activists say they are challenging the forum's motives with peaceful protests -- even puppets. The police say they are summoning thousands of officers to ensure the safety and civil rights of all involved.
If it were all that simple, of course, then the city would be welcoming a love-in, not bracing for a Super Bowl weekend of conflict.
The seeds for having the conference in New York this weekend were planted on Sept. 11, organizers say, when the forum's founder, a Swiss business professor named Klaus Schwab, happened to be in the city. Stunned, Mr. Schwab returned to Switzerland and proposed moving the annual event from its traditional location, the remote skiing village of Davos, to Manhattan as a demonstration of solidarity for a wounded city. (Critics of the conference say that the forum had actually worn out its welcome in Davos.)
Representatives of the forum talked of a move with Rudolph W. Giuliani, then in his final weeks as mayor. According to Charles D. McLean, the conference's spokesman, the mayor said: "Great, welcome to New York."
As a result of that agreement, some 3,000 heads of state, political theorists, cultural figures and -- in particular -- corporate leaders will begin arriving this morning for five days of discussions on such sober topics as global warming, worldwide recession and the threat of terrorism. Mr. McLean said that the recommendations that emerge from the conference are worked on year-round by the forum's members and employees, and that its proposals had influenced the decisions of the world.
He suggested that people who were not invited to the Waldorf this weekend should think of the event as "a global town hall of leaders from different sectors of society." He said that members and invited guests "come to our meetings because of a shared commitment to the forum's mission of improving the state of the world."
Among the many guests are the likes of Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu and Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations. But it mainly attracts the heads of international corporations who have paid about $25,000 for the chance to establish and burnish valuable business contacts amid all the somber theorizing. 
The forum also carries a certain egghead glitz: there are A-list gatherings at top restaurants; late-evening "nightcaps" with former President Bill Clinton and others; and tours of the city's sights, including, of course, ground zero. In one conference room at the Waldorf might be Secretary of State Colin Powell; down the hall, Peter Gabriel, the rock star who is listed in the roster of participants as "Peter B. Gabriel."
Finally, the World Economic Forum brings protesters by the thousands: anarchists, socialists, environmentalists, labor unions. They see the forum as a sinister force, an opportunity for a small group of elite capitalists to carve up the world as though it were a pizza with everything on it. Many have protested peacefully at similar economic conferences in the past, often using acts of civil disobedience. But a few have had violent confrontations with the police, most notably in Seattle in 1999 and Genoa in 2001. 
In recent weeks, the police and the demonstrators have monitored each other's preparations as best as they can, and have engaged in the kind of psyche-out posturing normally seen at a weigh-in for a boxing match. 
The police recently invited the media to watch a training exercise at Shea Stadium, at which police cadets, posing as demonstrators, disrupted mock motorcades and caused general mock mayhem. Activists complain that the police sought to frighten away protesters with the widely disseminated photographs of officers in riot gear.
Some activists have been conducting training sessions of their own, in the techniques of nonviolent confrontation (although law enforcement officials say that mischievous diversionary tactics have also been taught). "One thing we've found," said David R. Graeber, a member of an anarchist group called the Anti-Capitalist Convergence, "is that if everybody sits down, you don't look threatening, and it's hard for the cops to come in and start slugging everybody."
On Monday, police officials held a no-nonsense news conference at police headquarters. The overall message they imparted was zero tolerance; any infraction of the law, no matter how minor, will lead to incarceration.
In a way, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly played the "good cop" role. "I think people are certainly distressed, you might say, as a result of Sept. 11, and there may be very little tolerance," he said. "But we're here to make certain that these people who want to demonstrate do so peacefully. They have First Amendment rights; we are going to ensure that they are able to exercise those rights."
Then came Joseph J. Esposito, the chief of department, to fill the "bad cop" role. He said the Police Department was prepared "for that small percentage that are bent on destruction of property or other things of that nature."
On Tuesday, representatives from several protest groups held a long news conference at the Community Church of New York, in Midtown, to express similar resolve -- although with nowhere near the precision demonstrated by the police. One of the many speakers was so nervous that she had to pause in the midst of denouncing the people who would be meeting "behind the closed and heavily militarized doors of the Waldorf-Astoria."
They emphasized that they were interested in nonviolent demonstrations, and maintained that the violent outbreaks at previous economic conferences were blown out of proportion and mostly the fault of the police. They bristled at being asked, again, about vandalizing the property of large corporations. They said the tactic was used only rarely by a handful of people, and, as Mr. Graeber of the Anti-Capitalist Convergence put it, "A lot of people may feel that this may not be the moment."
The moment, of course, is the first raw months after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11. But Eric Laursen, a member of Another World Is Possible, an umbrella organization, pointed out that he and many others who planned to protest were New York residents who shared the city's grief. He said it was an insult to suggest that protests for which city permits had been issued were somehow unpatriotic.
Mr. Laursen said that a mother had called to ask if a rally on Saturday would be safe enough for her to take her 14-year-old son. "I told her it's not going to be one where we're running that kind of risk," he said. He said that the activists who sometimes destroyed property as a means of protest "have assured us that they're not going to do anything to compromise our march and rally."
Meanwhile, police officers are hanging outside the Starbucks stores throughout Manhattan. Is it because of the rich coffee -- or because they know something? Call it dramatic tension.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; 
Times Co. Reports 46% Drop In Fourth-Quarter Net Income

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income fell 46 percent as a weak advertising market more than offset cost cuts and gains in circulation income.
 The Times Company, which owns publications including The Times and The Boston Globe, posted net income of $74.1 million, or 48 cents a share, down from $137.8 million, or 83 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier, when the sale of three regional newspapers bolstered income. Revenue fell to $780.6 million from $927.1 million. 
 Excluding income from the sale of the papers, as well as several other unusual items, including the costs of reducing the work force, the company said profit in the quarter came to $76.9 million, down 31.5 percent from $112.1 million a year earlier. Calculated per share, the figure fell to 50 cents from 68 cents. 
The quarter proved to be the worst of the year for advertising, in terms of year-over-year change, and December -- always the strongest month of a year -- had the biggest percentage drop of any month. In December, ad revenue fell 19.8 percent for all the company's newspapers, with ad revenue off 23.5 percent at The Times; 20.6 percent at the New England newspaper group, which includes The Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette in Massachusetts; and 5.4 percent at its regional newspaper group.
But executives of the Times Company said that advertising trends were improving in January for most parts of the company. At The Times, ad revenue in January was down "in the low to midteens" on a percentage basis from the year before, said Russell T. Lewis, the president and chief executive of the Times Company. For the regional papers, the decline was in the low single digits. 
At The Globe, the decline was larger, in the mid-20's on a percentage basis, largely because of the publication of a semiannual special recruitment section called Big Help. That section carried 60 pages this year, down from 132 a year earlier.
The company did not release estimates for first-quarter profit, but executives said they expected 2002 to be a better year. "We believe there's light at the end of the tunnel, and it's not another train coming at us," Leonard P. Forman, the chief financial officer, said in a conference call with analysts. "We believe there's a second-half recovery coming."
Mr. Lewis said the company expected earnings per share, excluding special items, to rise in the "mid-single-digit to low-double-digit range" in 2002, assuming there is an economic recovery. Without a recovery, he said, "we believe modest earnings-per-share growth is still possible."
For all of 2001, the company reported a profit of $1.59 a share, excluding special items, down from $2.10 in 2000.
While advertising revenue fell in the fourth quarter, circulation revenue rose 9.1 percent, after adjusting for divested newspapers and the fact that the 2000 quarter had an extra week in it. The rise reflected rising circulation and higher prices. The company said it expected circulation revenue to increase 4 percent to 6 percent in 2002, aided by an increase in the price of home delivery for The Times, which will take effect next week and is expected to improve annual profit by at least $24 million.
The company's broadcast group said revenue fell 19.3 percent, to $38.1 million, in the quarter, while operating profit fell 38.4 percent, to $10.8 million. In 2000, the company's television stations had benefited from political advertising.
At New York Times Digital, the company's Internet operations, revenue fell 4.9 percent. But thanks to cost reductions, the digital operations reported a quarterly operating profit of $1.4 million, in contrast to a $12 million loss a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Fiscal News For Nassau: From Bad To Worse 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Jan. 30 

 BODY:
Just how bad is Nassau County's budget crisis? Take the previous deficit calculation and double it, the county executive said today. Fixing the problem will require steps he called "drastic" and "painful."
 County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi said that unless corrective action was taken, the projected deficit would reach a staggering $428 million in 2005. That is more than twice the previous estimate of $208 million, made a year ago, and nearly one-fifth of the current $2.2 billion budget. 
 It is also a shortfall on the same scale as the one Mr. Suozzi's fellow Democrats are projecting three or four years from now in New Jersey, which analysts in Washington and on Wall Street say faces the worst deficit of any state.
But while the fiscal problems of New Jersey and other states have been brought on largely by the recession and the Sept. 11 terror attacks, most of Nassau's quandary stems from its own longstanding mismanagement.
For years, the chronically gaping hole in Nassau's budget has been scrutinized and debated by auditors, bond raters and politicians. It prompted the state to impose a fiscal oversight board in 2000, and led to the Republicans' loss of control of the county government in November's elections, for the first time since World War I. On Tuesday, Nassau was rated dead last for fiscal management in a study of the nation's 40 largest counties by the Maxwell School of Public Policy at Syracuse University.
Today, Mr. Suozzi dropped a new piece of unwelcome news: a ballooning deficit.
"It's worse than we thought," he said at a news conference here. "We inherited the problem, and it's our job to solve the problem."
To close the gap, his administration is working on a four-year financial plan to submit to the state monitoring agency, the Nassau County Interim Finance Authority, known here as NIFA. The deadline is April 1, and if the authority finds the plan unacceptable, it can take control of Nassau's finances.
Balancing the budget is likely to require a combination of higher taxes and fees, service cuts and staff reductions. Nothing has been decided, Mr. Suozzi said, though he ruled out relying solely on a tax increase.
"Absolutely everything is on the table," Mr. Suozzi said. "People don't want their taxes raised. People don't want their services reduced. Something's got to give." 
The most immediate problem is to adjust this year's budget of about $2.2 billion, which Mr. Suozzi said threatens to veer into the red by as much as $30 million by the end of the fiscal year, in December. A deficit of that size would activate a law that forces a state fiscal takeover of the county in the event of an imbalance of at least 1 percent. Mr. Suozzi said that to prevent such a deficit, he would announce a series of actions next week.
Although he did not mention his predecessor by name, he blamed the administration of Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, for creating the deficit by bad budgeting. 
For example, the $22 million public works budget, prepared by Mr. Gulotta, is short by $2.8 million because the Department of Public Works has 544 workers -- 75 more than budgeted, Mr. Suozzi said. 
Calculations of inspection fees for weight scales and gasoline pumps were made using numbers for scales and pumps far beyond the numbers that actually exist in the county. "It is impossible to achieve," said Roger Bogsted, commissioner of the Office of Consumer Affairs, which conducts the inspections.
And at the Department of Recreation and Parks, cuts were made so arbitrarily that its equipment budget was listed at minus $117,050.
Mr. Suozzi denied that he was exaggerating the deficit to make himself look better for tackling it. "There's no political advantage in that," he said.
His announcement drew positive reactions. "We haven't seen the numbers yet, but we're pleased that he is being conservative in his numbers rather than unrealistically optimistic," said Richard M. Kessel, a member of the state oversight board.
The county's new comptroller, Howard S. Weitzman, a Democrat, said he was not surprised by the new deficit projections. "It could definitely be off that much," he said.
The County Legislature's Democratic majority leader, Judith A. Jacobs, said, "Our finance people always thought the figures were wrong." 
And Ed Ward, a spokesman for the Republican minority leader, Peter Schmitt, added, "Hopefully the county executive will give the Legislature and NIFA a plan that is going to meet the problems."

HEADLINE: The Statement By the Fed 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to leave interest rates unchanged: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to keep its target for the federal funds rate unchanged at 1 3/4 percent. 
 Signs that weakness in demand is abating and economic activity is beginning to firm have become more prevalent. With the forces restraining the economy starting to diminish, and with the long-term prospects for productivity growth remaining favorable and monetary policy accommodative, the outlook for economic recovery has become more promising. 
The degree of any strength in business capital and household spending, however, is still uncertain. Hence, the committee continues to believe that, against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future.

HEADLINE: In Rebirth of 'Silk City,' a Snag; 
Mayor's Indictment Tries the Patience of Paterson

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES 

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 30 

 BODY:
This much can be said of this bleak but battling community, hard by the Passaic River, that was forged by the Industrial Age, ruined by its demise and is still reeling from a century of labor strife, racial tensions, high crime rates and joblessness: at least there was no plague of locusts.
 It might seem, however, that long-suffering Paterson has been visited by just about every other adversity. The state's third-largest city ushered in the last century with a devastating fire in 1902 that laid waste to more than a quarter of the buildings in the city. Less than four weeks later, disaster struck again when a flood washed out virtually everything else. The next year, there was a tornado in July and then another flood in October. And those were just the natural calamities -- there would be decades more of social and economic calamities to come. 
 "There is a sadness here because there is so much potential and it just goes unrealized," said Flavia Alaya, a cultural historian at Ramapo College and a Paterson resident for more than 30 years. "And the longer its potential goes unrealized, the sadder it gets. You have these almost Biblical events. You stop waiting for good things to happen." 
And so it goes in Paterson, the Job of New Jersey cities, which is entering another hundred years of waiting for good things to happen.
The city's first major crisis of the new century might seem to pale next to those of the one just past. Last week, Mayor Martin G. Barnes was indicted by a federal grand jury and charged with accepting cash, vacations, home renovations and paid "female companionship" in exchange for granting city contracts.
On Monday, Mr. Barnes pleaded not guilty to the charges, which were outlined in a 40-count indictment prepared by the United States attorney's office in Newark. The product of a two-year investigation of a local contractor, the indictment says that Mr. Barnes accepted thousands of dollars' worth of trips and gifts, filed false tax returns and defrauded the Department of Housing and Urban Development of $29,000.
Mr. Barnes, 53, was released on $100,000 bail pending a hearing next month into the admissibility of tape recordings that prosecutors may use as evidence in the case. If convicted, the mayor could face up to 20 years in prison.
The allegations against Mr. Barnes have been the talk of this slice of north-central New Jersey, and they have also cast renewed attention on this largely anonymous town of 149,000 on Passaic County's eastern edge.
Paterson has long been one of the state's most impoverished communities -- it is New Jersey's third poorest city as well as its third largest. And today's blackened, punched-out, abandoned warehouses are a far cry from its turn-of-the-century heyday as "the Silk City," when its 8.5 square miles were crammed with as many as 400 mills and factories.
Today, city officials say, there are only four.
Its history of high crime rates, brought into stark relief by the beating death of a homeless man by 13 high school students in June, fueled an exodus of businesses and residents from the city through the 1980's and 90's. The Silk City has become so unseemly that the neighboring, affluent community of West Paterson has held elections three times over the past dozen years to consider changing its name to avoid any affiliation with it. (The efforts, including one in November, have all failed.)
But during the past five years, the city has inched closer to the makings of a renaissance of sorts.
Unemployment here, over 12 percent in the late 1990's, has fallen by 5 percent since 1997. Property values are up as much as 40 percent in parts of the city. Paterson's police force has returned to staffing levels not seen for nearly three decades. And, in what could be viewed as a different kind of civic cachet, Paterson has frequently been used as a location for the filming of the HBO series "The Sopranos."
But some fear that the indictment of Mr. Barnes may slow whatever tenuous momentum the city may have gained.
"With regard to the activities in the city, there's still a lot of buzz in the city itself," said Councilman William Kline, a frequent critic of the mayor's. "I hope that developers won't be discouraged by the mayor's problems, but there is great promise in Paterson, and we have a vision. I'd hate to see those visions and those hopes and dreams ruined because of this."
Bob Grant, the mayor's spokesman, said that any momentum in the city would not be slowed by Mr. Barnes's indictment.
"Fiscally the city is on a sound footing for the first time in 25, 30 years," Mr. Grant said. "As for the mayor's problems, we think he will eventually be vindicated."
As for the resurgence of Paterson, many here are hopeful but realistic. "It's a city looking for itself; we're kind of meandering along," said Giacomo De Stefano, a native of the city and director of the Paterson Museum. "Sometimes, I say to myself, 'Man, what happened to Paterson?' We had it and then we lost it."
Ms. Alaya, the Ramapo professor, said: "What happened to the Silk City is that the Silk City went out with the silk. Things changed when synthetics came along. Silk had lost its aura."
And so, too, in some ways had the Silk City.
Founded in 1791 on the banks of the Great Falls of the Passaic, Paterson was one of the nation's first planned industrial cities. Named for then-Gov. William Paterson, the city's first century saw the emergence of textile mills and factories, the arrival of immigrants looking for work and the rise of unions.
Then, at the turn of the century the calamities began: the fire in 1902, followed by a flood, a tornado and then another flood. And on a quick tour of this fading workers' town, with its abandoned warehouses and graffiti-strewn buildings, the ghosts of earlier days still linger.
The still-imposing factory buildings are humbled somewhat by their gap-toothed broken windows. Other buildings, their windows boarded up, seem to boast about their once-proud pasts with painted letters on their facades -- letters that fade a bit more each year. Paterson Silk Machinery Exchange, whispers one along Spruce Street.
The downtown is still bright and active, and the signs that the city is breaking away from its urban torpor can be seen in the renovated factories of the historic district, which have found a new life housing retail shops and small offices. The faces on the street reflect the change from a predominantly Irish and Italian community to one that is equal parts black, Hispanic and white.
There are also reminders of some of this city's native sons, including the poet Allen Ginsberg, the baseball Hall of Famer Larry Doby, and the comedian Lou Costello, who is commemorated with a statue in a small park not far from downtown.
The other day a disheveled man slept on a bench at one end of the park, and a man wearing a hooded jacket sat quietly rocking on another, a half dozen over-stuffed trash bags piled at his feet. Surveying the entire scene was the smiling, sculptured visage of the late Mr. Costello, his trademark derby splattered with a pale green patina of bird droppings.
Not far from the Costello memorial, James Barone sat on the steps of the Roma Soccer Club along Cianci Street.
"Once upon a time, this town was beautiful," said Mr. Barone, 73, adjusting his bifocals. "Now it's a joke. We used to have 12 movie houses and we don't got none today, not one."
A veteran of the dye houses that once seemed as common here as fire hydrants, Mr. Barone looked across a broad field and with his finger outlined the businesses that once stood there. "We had dance halls and everything," he said. "There was an Italian bakery there," he said of a spot where a parking lot stood. "It was just wonderful." 
"It was strictly ethnic, Irish and Italian; we had some blacks, too," said Mr. Barone, whose parents came to Paterson from Sicily. "We all got along. It was rough sometimes, but we all got along."
He paused. "It was Silk City then," he said. "Now, I don't know."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: RECONSTRUCTION; 
I.M.F. Backs Official Shift To U.S. Dollar By Afghans

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 30 

 BODY:
With its economy and monetary system in tatters, Afghanistan is weighing a plan to adopt the United States dollar as legal tender until it introduces a new currency.
 The governor of the Afghan central bank, Abdul Qadeer Fitrat, said this week that the government would decide soon whether to use the dollar to replace the local currency, the afghani, which has been ruinously devalued as warlords and counterfeiters have printed their own notes. 
 Afghanistan's move toward the dollar has also won support from the International Monetary Fund, which sent eight officials here this week on the fund's first visit in a decade.
"I personally see more benefits than impediments," said Warren Coats, of the fund's monetary and exchange department. "There are several versions of the afghani currency in circulation. That in itself creates an important problem." 
Mr. Coats said the dollar could serve as an anchor for Afghanistan's money supply for two to three years, while the government wrestles with how to introduce a new currency.
Other countries with weak currencies, notably Ecuador, have adopted the dollar. But few countries have had as corrupted a money supply.
The afghani was introduced after Soviet forces left in 1989, and continued to be used under the Taliban. Warlords who refused to recognize the Taliban signaled their rebellions -- and financed them -- by printing their own afghanis. Today, a 10,000-afghani note printed by Abdul Rashid Dostum, a warlord in Kunduz Province, is worth half a 10,000-afghani note from the central bank.
Most afghani notes, even those put out by the government, are printed in Russia. Afghanistan lacks a secure printing facility.
The I.M.F. and the World Bank, which also sent a delegation here this week, will have to do more than recommend printers. Afghanistan's currency woes are only the most visible manifestation of an economy that has given up any pretense to international standards.
Under the Taliban, the government kept little or no economic statistics, and did not bother with accounting. The dearth of data has left Afghanistan's interim government, and the fund and World Bank, groping for even the most basic information. Mr. Fitrat, who ran central bank before the Taliban, said he could not calculate the inflation rate because the Taliban kept no statistics on consumer prices. 
This lack of information poses a short-term problem because the interim government must prepare a new budget by March 21, the start of the new fiscal year.
Happily for the government, the afghani is not linked to the dollar or any other currency. So the government does not need reserves to prop up the exchange rate.
Indeed, the currency's value is determined in the freest market of all: Kabul's throbbing bazaar, where money changers trade six-inch piles of Afghanis for crisp $100 bills.
The rate changes constantly -- tracked not by currency traders but by rumors that course through the ranks of the money changers. In the wake of the I.M.F. support for using dollars, the afghani plunged to 34,000 for a dollar, from 27,000. 
Mr. Fitrat said he hoped to "remove some of the zeros" when Afghanistan introduces a new national currency. But before he does that, he must confront some ticklish political issues, not the least whether the notes should bear the images of Afghan leaders. The current afghanis picture buildings and landscapes; orthodox Muslims avoid using images of people.
Still, disputes over design could pale next to battles over how the government collects tax revenues and distributes money. The same warlords who print their own money are not likely to turn over cash from local taxes and license fees.
Despite the depth of Afghanistan's problems, the fund and the World Bank found a few bright spots.
The country has a legitimate government, said Alastair J. McKechnie, the World Bank's director for Afghanistan. Unlike some recipients of foreign aid, it is not deeply in debt; Mr. McKechnie put the amount of overdue loans at under $50 million.
Paul Chabrier, director of the Middle Eastern department at the fund, said he had discovered in a visit to the customs office in Kabul that it had raised $12 million in the past seven months through duties on imports. That proved, he said, that the government has the ability to raise money.
"It's not necessarily a poor country," Mr. Chabrier said. "It just needs to be put back together."
So where is the $12 million now?
"We don't know where the money went," Mr. Chabrier conceded with a shrug. "The Taliban may have looted it."

Fed Holds Rates Steady; Economy Defies Attacks
The Federal Reserve brought its yearlong campaign of interest rate cuts to an apparent end, voting to hold rates steady and citing signs of an incipient recovery.
 Earlier, the government reported that the economy had defied widespread predictions of a sharp contraction after the terrorist attacks to show a small growth rate in the last three months of 2001. Page A1. 

Stocks rose after the Fed left rates unchanged. The Dow rose 1.5 percent, and the Nasdaq and the S.& P. gained more than 1 percent. C10.

HEADLINE: BOXING; 
Tyson Investigated in Another Rape Complaint

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
The camps of Mike Tyson and Lennox Lewis said yesterday that they were looking to hold a heavyweight championship bout outside Nevada, even as the Las Vegas police were investigating a second rape complaint that was filed against Tyson this month.
 That complaint was brought by a woman who said Tyson raped her at his home in Las Vegas in November 2000, said Lt. Jeff Carlson, the commander of the sex crimes unit. The police recently concluded an investigation of accusations by a woman who said Tyson raped her at his home in September, and police officers plan to meet with Clark County prosecutors tomorrow to review the report. Carlson said the report showed there was probable cause to bring a criminal charge against Tyson. 
 Tyson is struggling through one of the lowest points in his career, as a result of the investigations and a ruling by the Nevada State Athletic Commission on Tuesday that denied Tyson a license to fight Lewis, who holds two heavyweight titles. 
The commission's 4-1 decision came a week after Tyson and Lewis got into a brawl at a news conference in Manhattan, where they had planned to announce their bout scheduled for April 6.
At a news conference yesterday in London, Lewis said he was optimistic that the bout would take place. "Mike Tyson is the last notch on Lennox Lewis's belt, the icing on my cake, and I'd love to sort it out," Lewis said. "It'd be disappointing if the fight doesn't go ahead."
Marina Capurro, a spokeswoman at the Showtime cable network, which has a contract with Tyson, said that Showtime had "been hearing from a lot of sites around the country and abroad." She said something might be worked out soon.
Denmark, South Africa, London and Detroit have been mentioned as possibilities, said Scott Miranda, a spokesman for Tyson. He said that Tyson was training and "getting back into his routine."
Tommy Hearns Entertainment, based in Detroit, faxed an application to the Michigan State Athletic Board of Control yesterday to hold a Tyson-Lewis bout. The board grants boxing licenses, and promoters who want to stage a bout must file a separate application for the event. Maura Campbell, a board spokeswoman, said a fax did not count as a formal application.
Hearns, a former world champion fighter, said in a telephone interview that "we would like to be part of the negotiations for that fight."
"We've had Mike here before," he said. "We don't expect to have any problems with his fight at all."
Hearns's lawyer, Michael Smith, said he had already placed calls to the Tyson and Lewis camps.
Campbell said that if Tyson wanted to fight in Michigan, the board would probably grant him a license unless he was suspended in another state, which is not the case. The Michigan board has the authority to look at violations that take place during a fight but is limited in what it can do before a bout, she said. Even criminal charges are usually not enough to reject a license application, Campbell said.
There is little chance that a city like Detroit can bring in the kind of gambling revenues that would have flooded into Las Vegas for a Tyson-Lewis bout. But the Detroit area, as well as nearby Canadian towns, does have several casinos, including a branch of the MGM Grand, whose Las Vegas location was willing to pay $14 million to stage the bout. If the fight were held in Detroit, it would probably be at Joe Louis Arena, Cobo Arena or a similar site.
In October 2000, Hearns promoted a bout between Tyson and Andrew Golota, in which Golota quit after the second round. Before the bout, the Michigan boxing commission was upset that Tyson made a mockery of some of its rules, including refusing to give a urine sample, Campbell said. The commission could do nothing before the fight, but it negotiated with Tyson's lawyers afterward to have Tyson give the commission a $200,000 "contribution" that was later given to charities, she said.
As for possibly holding the fight in New York, Raymond W. Kelly, the state's boxing commissioner and the city's police commissioner, said that "we would honor the decision of the Nevada athletic commission."
New Jersey has also been mentioned as a potential site. Larry Hazzard, the state's boxing commissioner, did not return calls seeking comment yesterday.
A fight outside the United States would not be "economically viable" for HBO or Showtime, said Bob Arum, a boxing promoter.
If a rape charge is brought against Tyson, then his passport could be held by a court.
Carlson, of the Las Vegas police, said the investigation into the second accusation would probably take at least a month and that Tyson or his lawyer would be questioned. The woman in that case filed a complaint in another state after the November 2000 incident but, Carlson said, a "lack of communication" prevented the Las Vegas police from learning about it until last month.
Miranda said Tyson was cooperating fully with the investigation.
Tyson was convicted in 1992 of rape and served more than three years in an Indiana prison.

HEADLINE: Japan Premier Taking Heat Over Firing Of Minister 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 30 

 BODY:
Japan's reformist prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, whose power derives primarily from high approval ratings in opinion polls, faced a potential crisis today as criticism piled up over his firing of his popular foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka.
 Mr. Koizumi acknowledged the problem at a news conference today, insisting that he would still press on with his vaunted program of reform. "Yes," he said in answer to a question about Mrs. Tanaka, "my decision may affect the stability of my administration." 
 The prime minister has only a small organized faction of support in Parliament. Since taking power last year and winning a far higher popular standing than a series of bland predecessors, he has largely succeeded in winning passage of legislation by using his public support to intimidate opponents inside his governing Liberal Democratic Party. 
In a Mainichi newspaper poll published last weekend, the approval rating for his cabinet was 72 percent.
Conservatives oppose Mr. Koizumi's plans for deregulation and privatization, pushing instead for the tried -- and failed -- recipe of boosting government spending to revive the economy.
Many economists, deeply aware that Japan is the most indebted nation in the world and is enduring its fourth recession in a decade, argue instead that a strong prime minister is needed to push through laws and procedures to cut the country's backlog of bad loans.
On Feb. 17, President Bush is to come here on a two-day visit. He is expected to appeal for the return of the world's second-largest economy to growth.
Mr. Koizumi may find that his dismissal of Mrs. Tanaka makes it harder to rally support, since the move was widely seen by reformers as a sop to conservatives in his party.
Yoichi Masuzoe, a Liberal Democratic Party senator sympathetic to Mr. Koizumi's pro-market economic approach, said: "Today I got dozens of telephone calls from the housewives, the ladies, saying, 'You have to defend Mrs. Tanaka, and Koizumi's decision is a mistake.' In terms of popular support, it really harms the Prime Minister for the moment. Maybe his support rate will be decreased by 10 percent."
The firing took place on Tuesday night just before midnight and immediately drew widespread attention. The Japan Broadcasting Corporation said its viewer ratings had soared to three times the normal level for the midnight period.
"Hard-core supporters of Tanaka may leave, and that will actually decrease Koizumi's popularity," Ikuo Kabashima, a political science professor at Tokyo University, warned in an interview today.
Analysts say the prime minister risked his credibility by using an apparently trivial pretext for dismissing the foreign minister: a dispute over an attempt to bar two nongovernmental groups from attending the Afghan aid conference in Tokyo last week.
To appear evenhanded in the war between a political minister and the career civil servants, Mr. Koizumi also fired the Foreign Ministry's ranking bureaucrat, Vice Minister Yoshiji Nogami.
Taking some tension out of the political crisis, Ms. Tanaka, a member of Parliament, said today that she would continue to support the prime minister "from the shadows."
Another way to offset the departure of Ms. Tanaka, the telegenic daughter of a former prime minister, would be to replace her with Sadako Ogata, who for 10 years, until December 2000, was the United Nations high commissioner for refugees.
Mrs. Ogata speaks fluent English and impressed the roughly 60 foreign ministers and heads of government at the Afghan aid conference.
Three Tokyo newspapers said Mrs. Ogata, 74, had been "tapped" for the job. Mrs. Ogata, who lives in New York much of the time, would have to give up a research position at the Ford Foundation, which she is using to write a book. This evening in Tokyo, her husband, Shijuro Ogata, was packing his bags for a 10-day trip to New York. He said he did not know if she had been offered the job, and she declined to comment to reporters in New York.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan in Parliament yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: THE OVERVIEW; 
Rich and Powerful Gathering At Elite Forum on Economy

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
In keeping with the times, the way to the site of the grand annual retreat of the world's movers and shakers was a maze of police barriers, concrete barricades, flashing lights and blue uniforms yesterday. But once inside the Waldorf-Astoria, it was more like the start of summer camp.
 Many who arrived on the eve of the opening today had been there before, and dropped their satchels and attache cases to clasp a hand and slap a shoulder. Many were men who had the air of money and power, but there were also third world diplomats, women business executives, clergy, academics and journalists. 
 The list of the 2,500 participants ran the gamut from celebrity C.E.O.'s like Bill Gates and Steve Forbes on through Russian oligarchs, kings and prime ministers, senators and even patriarchs.
This was the 31st World Economic Forum, an annual gathering to which an invitation is perceived -- by participants and critics at least -- as a membership card in a global economic and political elite.
It was also the first held outside the Swiss ski resort of Davos, which has provided the name by which the forum is popularly known. The organizers moved it after the Sept. 11 attacks, and after the Swiss government had balked at the rising cost of providing security. 
Unlike other conferences, this one does not expect to produce decisions or papers. This year, the theme is "Leadership in Fragile Times: a Vision for a Shared Future." But participants like Delaware Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and the social scientist Samuel P. Huntington of Harvard are scheduled to discuss "the root cause of conflict," while Jeff Bezos of Amazon.com was listed on a panel on "connecting to consumers in uncertain times."
Leaders of 1,000 "foremost companies" from around the world pay about $25,000 each in annual dues and about $6,000 per participant to attend the annual meeting, and many come back.
"I've been coming here for 14 years, and even though it's expensive, it's a lot cheaper than trying to meet all these people any other way," said the Lebanese head of an international trading company who asked not to be identified.
Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International and another veteran of Davos conclaves, said the value was in the "cross-fertilization of ideas."
"It's the quality and level of the people, and the stimulating nature of the format," he said. "You get to discuss ideas you might not face in everyday business."
To offset the image of a global establishment, and to foment discussions, there are sizable contingents from other worlds -- 40 religious leaders, 200 experts from think tanks and various academic centers, 350 news media representatives and 40 union leaders.
Organizers estimate that a quarter of the 2,500 participants have come from developing countries.
Traditionally, Davos includes a large dollop of partying. Even in these fiscally tight times there are a dozen private affairs. The Coca-Cola Company hosts its annual soiree at the Four Seasons Restaurant. Other companies have booked landmarks like Le Cirque 2000, and Goldman Sachs & Company has reserved the Rainbow Room for a Super Bowl party on Sunday.
That has not prevented critics from painting the forum in the darkest colors. "The World Economic Forum will celebrate war in Afghanistan and the Middle East, attacks on civil liberties, and corporate tax cuts," proclaimed a group called A.N.S.W.E.R. (Act Now to Stop War and End Racism) in its call for demonstrations which will get under way in earnest with marches on Saturday.
"At the New York W.E.F. summit, the world's richest C.E.O.'s will collaborate with the world's most powerful politicians to set the global economic agenda," declared another group, Students for Global Justice.
Whether the protests reach the violence of the meeting last year in Davos remains to be seen. Some opposition groups acknowledge that a clash with "New York's finest" in the aftermath of Sept. 11 would not sit well with the public.
Klaus Schwab, the Swiss business professor who created and still rules the Geneva-based World Economic Forum, bridles at the image critics paint of the gatherings of greedy corporate chiefs discussing how to fatten their bottom lines.
"I think that is a very demagogic, simplified and polarizing way to describe people," he said in an interview. "You assume that all these people are the same. You make a caricature. If you look at the decision-makers who are here, there are certainly some who fit this description, but it is not a homogeneous group. Not every C.E.O. is just into making money, is greedy and so on."
Mr. Schwab said 40 percent of the participants are C.E.O.'s, and about 30 percent of the rest are "idealists" -- a category that evidently included environmentalists, religious leaders and the like.
"Maybe I'm too much of an idealist, but there are also fathers, they have a younger generation and they think in terms of the environment and so on" he said.
Among these was Robert Kinloch Massie of the Global Reporting Initiative, which seeks to develop guidelines for reporting on the economic, environmental and social performance for corporations.
"I'm a believer in getting people with diverse backgrounds into the same room," Mr. Massie said as he waited to register.
Over the years the forum has been the venue for important decisions. In 1994, Yasir Arafat of the Palestinian Authority -- a regular who is blocked from attending this year by Israeli tanks -- reached a historic agreement with the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres.
Two years earlier, the South African president, F. W. de Klerk, met in Davos with Nelson Mandela -- their first joint appearance outside South Africa.
Veteran participants said that in general the participation of government officials has steadily grown through the history of the forum, changing its character from a business meeting to the broader discussion of current issues. 
But this year, the Bush White House is mostly staying away. Colin L. Powell, the secretary of state, and Paul O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, will be the highest ranking representatives. Unlike Bill Clinton, who came as president, President Bush does not go in for a lot of talk.
But at its core, the conference has been an attempt to focus the formal workshops and meetings on issues rather than business. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, for example, will debate trends with the likes of Zbigniew Brzezinski, Shimon Peres and George Soros.
Other discussions likely to stir at least curiosity are one on "understanding global anger," featuring the chairman of McDonald's, Jack Greenberg, or another on "the politics of apology," with Archbishop Emeritus Desmond Tutu and Elie Wiesel.
Whatever the panels, most of the talk will center on the weakening economies of Europe and America and the war on terrorism. "This requires us, to borrow the title of another workshop in the program, to 'rethink safety and security in business and in government,' " as the introduction to the program noted. "In many ways, the crucial question is how we are going to address the new forms and dimensions of risk."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
MANPOWER SAYS IT WILL MISS FIRST-QUARTER ESTIMATES

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Manpower, a provider of temporary labor, will miss analysts' forecasts for its first-quarter earnings as the weakened economy has slowed demand. Profit will be 6 cents to 10 cents a share on revenue that will lag year-earlier levels, the chief executive, Jeffrey A. Joerres, said during a conference call. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected the company to earn 15 cents a share. The company, based in Milwaukee, made the forecast while reporting fourth-quarter results. Manpower earned $26 million, or 34 cents a share, down from $53.5 million, or 70 cents, a year earlier. Sales declined 9.5 percent to $2.82 billion from $3.12 billion.

HEADLINE: Chrysler to Increase Vehicle Incentive Offers 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 30 

 BODY:
The Chrysler Group reversed course today and said that it would increase incentive offers to its customers because of a slump in January sales.
 The automaker, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, cut back its offers at the end of last year. After General Motors started a post-Sept. 11 interest-free financing blitz, the Big Three offered over $2,000 a vehicle in incentives. 
 Chrysler went along with the deals, but its top executives said repeatedly that the deals were a bad idea for the domestic automakers and were causing losses to widen. Foreign automakers like Toyota Motor and Honda Motor have largely avoided such deals and maintained strong sales, and the weakness of the yen has provided a further cost advantage. For G.M., the only one of the Big Three to make a profit last year, the deals have been an opportunity to buy back lost market share.
Chrysler, the No. 3 automaker in the nation, said that continued heavy incentive spending by G.M. and Ford Motor made its play for thrift untenable.
"We were having real trouble getting store traffic because our competitors were out there advertising these huge deals," said James Schroer, Chrysler's executive vice president for global sales and marketing.
Mr. Schroer added that the Big Three's heavy reliance on incentive spending was a "zero-sum game" that the company hoped would end. Ford and Chrysler each hope, at best, to break even this year, though many analysts are expecting another year of red ink for both companies.
Already, industry sales appear to have slowed in January from the heady pace at the end of last year as consumer enthusiasm for incentives has worn down. Over all, industry sales in January are at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 16.2 million vehicles, according to a recent projection by J. D. Power & Associates, compared with a rate of 18.2 million in the fourth quarter and 16.9 million in January 2001.
"It's well off of the 18.2 million of the fourth quarter and consistent with most people's expectations that the market has slowed down this year," said Robert Schnorbus, chief economist at J. D. Power. 
That means competition will intensify for what is left. G.M. shifted from its interest-free financing plan to rebates of $2,002 on most of its vehicles to market its deals around a new pitch. Ford also shifted to generous rebates of up to $2,500.
Chrysler, in the meantime, moved to a less-potent plan that included scattered rebates varying by state and model, as well as a seven-year, 100,000-mile power train warranty.
Mr. Schroer said the company would be increasing its incentive spending again, starting today, because it had lost ground in January. The new plans will include rebates of $2,500 for the Dodge Durango, for several minivans and for the Jeep Grand Cherokee, as well as continuing the power train warranty. Most other vehicles will have $1,500 rebates along with the warranties.
"It's a step up from where we were in January but still a step below where G.M. and Ford are," Mr. Schroer said. "We have to dial up the burner again to be able to compete with the accelerated deals from G.M. and Ford."

HEADLINE: As Bush's Stature Rises . . . 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
It will take a lot more than Dick Gephardt's tepid address on Tuesday night to interfere with the bond that is developing between President Bush and the American people.
 Mr. Bush was supposed to have been a man of generally low wattage who needed a map to navigate a simple declarative sentence. But he got everybody's attention with a masterful speech soon after the Sept. 11 attacks, and since then he's drawn high marks and admiration for his handling of the war on terror. 
 "Saturday Night Live" continues to mock him mercilessly, but Mr. Bush's ratings in public opinion polls are extraordinary. And those sky-high approval ratings seem to reflect a genuine affection for the man, warm feelings that run much deeper than those shown his father in the immediate aftermath of the gulf war. 
The Democrats are faced with the simple fact that most Americans like their president, and are rooting for him.
Mr. Bush, in turn, has exhibited a sense of command and a comfort level with the presidency that was lacking before Sept. 11. You don't hear many jokes anymore about Dick Cheney being in charge.
The public's enthusiastic embrace of Mr. Bush, when combined with the sense of vulnerability most Americans still feel regarding terror, makes the president a much more formidable political foe than his father. You could feel the tremor of fear that surged through the national audience when Mr. Bush said, during his State of the Union address, "Thousands of dangerous killers, schooled in the methods of murder, often supported by outlaw regimes, are now spread throughout the world like ticking time bombs, set to go off without warning."
Even those Americans who don't particularly like George W. Bush -- and there are a fair number of them -- do not have the luxury of hoping he'll fail.
So this is the difficult environment in which Mr. Gephardt and others who oppose Mr. Bush on a range of important issues are forced to fight. For example, how do you generate concern over the fact that Mr. Bush apparently attended the Ronald Reagan school of economics? Critics complain that by expending enormous sums of money on the military at the same time that he is slashing taxes, Mr. Bush is speeding recklessly toward the long dark tunnel of budget deficits.
If the president is concerned about this he hasn't shown it. On Tuesday night he coolly urged Congress to "make these tax cuts permanent."
He addressed the matter of the struggling economy by saying, "When America works, America prospers. So my economic security plan can be summed up in one word: jobs."
The only problem was that he offered no job-creation plan, no blueprint on how to proceed. Worse, even as unemployment is going up, the administration's support for job training programs is going down. It would not be prudent to bet a lot of money on big-time job creation by the Bush administration.
But it would be even less prudent at the moment to attack the president on this, or any, issue. Americans are deployed in combat arenas overseas, and at home there remains the threat of additional terror attacks.
So Dick Gephardt and other Democratic leaders are doing the dance of avoidance, trying hard to make their points without appearing confrontational. "Now," said Mr. Gephardt, "is not a time for finger-pointing or politics as usual."
Mr. Bush has told us that the war against terror will continue indefinitely, and might well widen. He gave lip service in his speech to some issues of particular interest to Democrats and working families, like improvements in the public education system and a so-called patients' bill of rights. But advocates are not holding their breath. Mr. Bush made it clear that there will be very little money left for such initiatives.
Meanwhile, the ranks of the jobless and the homeless are growing. A renewed crisis in health care is brewing. Most Americans, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, are having trouble paying their bills.
These are issues that generally favor the Democrats. But George W. Bush is very popular right now. And there's a war going on. And the fear of terror is pervasive.
So the Democrats are more or less cooling their heels, placed in check by a fellow who was initially viewed, at best, as a political lightweight.

HEADLINE: An Address Sets a Tone Of New York Optimism 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has some very bad news for New York City. But yesterday, he chose only to hint at it, instead giving a speech peppered with many proposals that have wound their way through government before, and heaping teaspoons of optimism that New York is already gingerly stepping into its best days. 
 In his 40-minute address to the City Council, Mr. Bloomberg took pains to be inclusive, congratulating the new Council speaker, Gifford Miller, and singling out the Latino and Puerto Rican Cultural Center as one of the city's cultural jewels. And even as he cautioned that austerity was the mode of the day, he nearly parroted President Bush when he said: "I am pleased to report to you that the state of the city is strong." 
 Many of the mayor's signature proposals for the first year of his term were either borrowed from his predecessors or were at least visions that had undergone tweaking. 
Mr. Bloomberg's call for what he referred to as tort reform, his insistence on abolishing local school boards along with the Board of Education, and his proposal for economic development on Manhattan's West Side have all been raised by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani or go back even farther. The establishment of new recreational facilities on Randalls Island required Mr. Bloomberg's approval, but the plans were laid by Mr. Giuliani.
Even Mr. Bloomberg's idea for a "311" call system for citizens to use instead of individual government help lines was explored, albeit in a much more limited version, by the Giuliani administration, which decided that it was not practical.
As for tort changes -- calls for capping punitive damages and the fees for lawyers who bring lawsuits against government -- those proposals have made their way through the State Capitol for decades and stand about as good a chance of happening as when they were first proposed.
What is more, many of Mr. Bloomberg's ideas, like ballot reform, mayoral control of the Board of Education and tort revisions, would require the acquiescence of Albany. Others, like plans for developing the city's waterfronts and keeping social services intact, require money.
Indeed, two interesting dramas will unfold over the next few months of the Bloomberg mayoralty -- the struggle between his expansive social policy agenda and limited resources, and his pursuit of some of Mr. Giuliani's dreams, with a different style. 
Mr. Bloomberg received his one standing ovation for hammering away at one order of business Mr. Giuliani failed to finish, but perhaps cared about the most: the troubled Board of Education. Calling for the abolition of the local school boards and mayoral control of the schools, Mr. Bloomberg said: "We do not need more commissions; we do not need more studies; we have too long waited for change. It is time to act." 
Applause filled the City Council chamber as dozens of onlookers, including Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy, rose to their feet. By contrast, when Mr. Bloomberg noted that tort revision could result in "over $6,000 in extra salary we could otherwise give to each of our 80,000 teachers," there was only the sound of one set of hands clapping somewhere in the back of the room. 
In stressing his goal of gaining control over the board, and spending the greatest amount of time on that one issue, Mr. Bloomberg appeared to be staking out a significant area on which he expected his mayoralty to be judged, and expressing confidence that he could get the job done. 
Mr. Bloomberg explored some new ground. He called for reforming the way that people vote, particularly on referendums, which are often very difficult to find or understand under the current system. 
He also said that he would rewrite the annual Mayor's Management Report, a seemingly intentionally impenetrable document that outlines the administration's accomplishments. Rewriting it is so important a task, he said, that he has assigned it to the respected and overburdened deputy mayor for operations, Marc V. Shaw. And calling for more openness in government, as personified by Mr. Bloomberg's open-air office in City Hall, is a campaign theme that he clearly wants to make good on. 
In tone and style, Mr. Bloomberg distinguished himself from Mr. Giuliani, as he has several times since taking office. He gave his speech in the Council's chamber during one of its stated meetings, letting the members stay in their fancy leather seats, rather than clearing the room at a time of his choosing and replacing the furniture with folding chairs, as was Mr. Giuliani's wont.
Mr. Bloomberg's gestures did not end there. The city's comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum and the five borough presidents all were congratulated for their election victories. The mayor promised that his press office would meet monthly with minority journalists. And is there a formal occasion in City Hall that David N. Dinkins will not attend in the Bloomberg administration? 
Mr. Bloomberg, whose speaking style has improved greatly even in the last few months, did pepper his remarks with several odd idioms and shibboleths. Improving education, he insisted, "does not mean rearranging the deck chairs on the deck of our educational Titanic." And clearly the mayor did not quite mean to say "The rappelling gavel of tort liability ultimately hammers the taxpaying public," but whoever wrote the line did him no favors.
But Mr. Bloomberg is also displaying his art for one-liners, as when he called once again for elected officials to cut back their budgets. "If you cannot find ways to do more with less," he said, "I will be happy to send in my staff to show you how."

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: ORGANIZER; 
The 'Chief Visionary' Discusses His Creation

BYLINE:  By JOYCE WADLER 

 BODY:
Klaus Schwab can't remember the name of the Saudi prince he ran into in the lobby of the Waldorf-Astoria, but no matter. 
 He knows a prince when he sees one, even if the fellow was dressed in jeans and sneakers and a corduroy jacket, and the prince knew Mr. Schwab, who is the president of the World Economic Forum. 
 "Your Royal Highness," Mr. Schwab said. 
"Professor Schwab," the prince said.
There was a courteous little chat. The prince, who turned out to be Abdullah bin Faisal bin Turki al-Abdullah al-Saud, governor of the Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority, was delighted to be here. The defense minister was keen to come, the prince said, but he had just had an operation on his back.
"I know," said Mr. Schwab, in their chance meeting this week. 
Did Mr. Schwab, head of the event that brings 3,000 of the most powerful people in the world together in New York this week, really know that the defense minister had had surgery? Or was he vamping? 
He knew, Mr. Schwab, said, because of his very good people. As he keeps saying, the World Economic Forum is not Klaus Schwab.
Right. How was Mr. Schwab able to recognize this particular prince?
"I had a private meeting with the crown prince in Riyadh," Mr. Schwab said. "I remember his face."
So it goes. Ask the German-born Mr. Schwab, by training a mechanical engineer and economist, about the World Economic Forum and Mr. Schwab will insist, in German-accented English, that much of the program for this year's conference was put together by his staff.
Then he clarified.
"I am the chief visionary, the chief strategist," Mr. Schwab said, in a masterstroke of simultaneous self-promotion and self-deprecation. "I have not been involved except in some delicate sessions where all the top Irish people for the first time from Northern Ireland will sit together. I have also been particularly involved in everything with the religious leaders." 
Political influence? Newt Gingrich, introducing Klaus Schwab at a forum meeting, reportedly called him "a social maitre d'."
The curious thing about this is that Mr. Schwab, 63, is such a stiff, serious, formal fellow. If on one end of the range of human emotion there is Sally Field accepting her Academy Award, on the other end, balancing her nicely, is Klaus Schwab. 
Meet him on the Saturday before the conference and he'll proudly point out that he is not wearing a tie because it is the weekend. He'll also profess a willingness to be photographed in his shirt-sleeves. 
Then, unable to bear it, he cracked. He cracked when a photographer started shooting, during a discussion of the former Enron chief Kenneth L. Lay, who was on the list of attendees, and then, like the promise of dot-com riches, was gone.
Why did Mr. Schwab's people disinvite Kenneth Lay?
"Why? Because at the moment the company went into bankruptcy, they did not fit anymore the criteria of our membership. I must put on the jacket," Mr. Schwab said, with the most anxiety he had displayed until the subject of a Wall Street Journal investigative article came up.
"If you look at the invitees, we have our 1,000 member companies, you have to be the leader in your field, and the moment the company would run into bankruptcy or officially indicted, which as far as I know is not the case, we would suspend it."
Ask him about a typical day at home in Geneva and he runs through a routine that's as precise as a Swiss watch. Arise at 6:20. Exercise at 7.
Parties at his home can also be sobering. Mr. Schwab taught business strategy at a Swiss university for 28 years, and a guest at one dinner party recalled being given a discussion topic. 
Humor is not Mr. Schwab's strong suit. Still, it is there. Speaking of Hilde, his wife of 31 years, he says she is eight years his junior. Told eight years would probably be considered a slight difference to his chief executive members, he smiled. 
"With them it's probably double, probably triple, given the trend of modern times," he said.
He acknowledges security concerns in moving the conference out of Switzerland, but he has personal reasons too. Mr. Schwab was in New York on Sept. 11, as was his adult son, who works for an American company. His son had a meeting in the World Trade Center that afternoon. As for Mr. Klaus, he remembers wartime bombing.
Mr. Schwab was born in 1938 in Ravensburg, Germany. His father was the director of a Swiss company. The family grew up 15 miles from the Swiss border and could visit Switzerland throughout the war. Mr. Schwab was much affected by the idea that "you could cross a line and on one side there was peace and on the other side there was war." 
He studied engineering in deference to his father, but was also drawn to economics, so he studied both simultaneously in Switzerland, earning two doctoral degrees. His engineering degree required a year of factory work. He recalls 40-minute lunch breaks. 
"When you work at a machine, you get very dirty hands," he said. "The big question for me was do I go wash my hands and get them completely clean, and then I just have 20 minutes to queue up in the cafeteria. As you know we have union leaders" -- 40 out of 2,700 participants this year, by his organization's count -- "and it gives me still today great respect for them. I wouldn't like to miss this experience."
In 1965, Mr. Schwab went to Harvard to study business and politics. Returning to Europe, he had an idea: Europeans, concerned about the rising American business challenge, would probably pay to learn about American business practices. The first meeting was held in Davos, Switzerland, in 1971.
Eventually, the World Economic Forum become host to the world's wealthiest and most powerful people. In 1998, Mr. Schwab set up the Schwab Foundation for Social and Economic Development. 
Two years later, on opening day of the Davos meeting, The Wall Street Journal ran an article citing "a confusing web" of his "overlapping personal and professional interests, especially when it comes to the forum's for-profit initiatives.". Among the findings were that Mr. Schwab, shortly after a forum contract was awarded to an American Internet consulting company, USWeb Corporation, became a member of the board and received stock options. The Swiss Federal Supervisory Board for Foundations investigated and found no improprieties. 
Mr. Schwab, asked about these accusations, is hurt.
"I was a member of USWeb and like any member I got stock options," he said. "I wanted to make the beneficiaries the foundation, but I was advised by legal counsel stock options had to be held in the name of the member. But for me it was always clear that the beneficiary was the foundation."
He says, in answer to questioning, that today he is on the boards of two profit-making companies, Daily Mail General Trust in England and Bank Vontobel, a private bank in Zurich.
"But why shouldn't I?" he asked. "If you ask the head of M.I.T. or the big universities, they are sitting on boards."
"I have nothing to reproach me," he said. "What is key is nobody ever can prove, can show," he rephrased, "I never made one dollar based on using my privileged relationship with the forum for me personally."
